r.en: Account of the production of the erin workers. 
r.en: Lu-Šara is the foreman, son of Lugal-inim-gina. 
r.en: It is (a period of) 12 months: 
r.en: from the month “Harvest” (1st month) 
r.en: until the month “Dumuzi” (12th month); 
r.en: year: “The boat of Enki was caulked”. 
r.en: 216 gur, 3 barig 5 ban 5 sìla barley (measured according to the) royal (standard), 
r.en: 35 gur emmer, 
r.en: 16 gur wheat 
r.en: from ARAD. 
r.en: 3 gur barley 
r.en: restored from the deficit 
r.en: of the fattener Bida. 
r.en: Together, the equivalent barley: 286 gur, 3 barig 5 ban 5 sila. 
r.en: 36 female laborers, (each of whom received) 3 ban (per month), 
.en: from month “Barley brought to the harbor” (month 3 of the Umma calender) 
.en: in the year “Harši” (Šulgi 48) 
.en: the completed day 23, 
.en: until month “Dumuzi” (month 12), the completed day 20, 
.en: its labor: 9,612 female laborer days, 
.en: from Ur-Urtab. 
.en: 36 female laborers, (each of whom received) 3 ban (per month), 
.en: from month “Dumuzi” (month 12) 
.en: in the year “Harši” (Šulgi 48) 
.en: the completed day 20 of the month “Dumuzi” (month 12) 
.en: to month “Bricks cast in moulds” (month 2) 
.en: in the year following “Harši” (Amar-Suen 1) 
.en: the completed day 8, 
r.en: its labor: 1,728 female laborer days, 
r.en: from Dingira. 
r.en: 123 1/3 (days), labor of the “free” days of the deceased female laborers. 
r.en: 3 female laborers, each 48 days, 
r.en: its labor: 144 (days) 
r.en: Total: 11,6071/3 female laborer days. 
r.en: is the debit. 
r.en: Therefrom: 
r.en: 1,914 (female laborer days) labor of the “free” days of the female laborers. 
.en: 184 gur, 2 barig 5 ban dabin flour, 
.en: 17 gur, 2 barig 1 ban 5 sila sig-flour, 
.en: 16 gur, 3 barig 1 ban “pounded” flour, 
.en: the work its labor is 6,559 1/2 days. 
.en: 1 gur, 1 barig 3 ban 6 sila fine pea-flour, 
.en: its labor: 49 1/2 days. 
.en: 3 barig 1 ban fine, ground ninda of the type zigiduhhum, 
.en: its labor: 91/2 days 
.en: 18 gur šagina pea-flour, 
.en: its labor: 675 days. 
.en: Basag, the general. 
.en: 1 gur, barig 8 sila flour, 
.en: loss (?), flour “filled” into the house. 
.en: sealed document of Lu-dingira, 
.en: its labor: 37 (days), 
.en: 22 1/2 (volume-)sar of soil, 
r.en: per (female) digger 10 (volume-)shekels (per day), 
r.en: labor of the female laborers involved: 270 days. 
r.en: sealed document of Ur-Namnunka. 
r.en: 232 (female laborer days as) labor of the female laborers who winnowed barley, 
r.en: the sealed tablets involved: 3, 
r.en: sealed document of ARAD. 
r.en: 24 female laborer days of the female laborers who loaded flour onto the barge, 
r.en: sealed document of Lu-Šara, the son of Alla. 
r.en: 19 female laborer days 
.en: straw carried to the temple of Šulgi, 
.en: sealed document of Akala, the nubanda. 
.en: 276 female laborers, labor of female laborers stationed “in milk.” 
.en: sealed document of Adumu. 
.en: 222 (female laborers), labor of the female laborers who did not go to bala (service) ..., 
.en: sealed document of Adu. 
.en: 25 female laborers in 7 days went to the bala(-service), 
.en: in 3 days returned from the bala(-service), 
.en: its labor: 250 days. 
.en: Dead: Geme-..., 
.en: from the month “nesag offering” (month 4) on. 
.en: Dead: Geme-Ninurta, 
.en: Dead: Luzi, daughter of Ili-bani, 
.en: Dead: Nin-lama, female slave of Adalal 
.en: from the month “Šulgi” (month 10) on. 
.en: Dead: Me-Urbartab, 
.en: from month “Dumuzi” (month 12), day 20 on, 
.en: its labor: 740 (days), 
r.en: in the year “Harši was destroyed” (Šulgi 48) 
r.en: until month “Bricks cast in moulds” (month 2) 
r.en: the completed day 8 
r.en: of the year following “Harši and Kimaš were destroyed” (Amar-Suen 1), 
r.en: 334 days of the arzana female laborers. 
r.en: sealed tablet of Lugal-nig-lagare. 
r.en: Total: 19 gur, 1 barig 3 ban 6 sila šagina pea flour, 
r.en: the bala barley involved: 1 gur, 4 barig 3 ban 91/2 sila 6 shekels, 
r.en: total: 185 gur, 3 barig 5 ban 8 sila dabin flour, 
.en: total: 34 gur, 2 ban 5 sila sig-flour, 
.en: total: 3 barig 1 ban ground zigiduhhum ninda, 
.en: the bala barley involved: 3 barig 1 ban, 
.en: the barley involved: 276 gur, 2 barig 2 ban 3 1/2 sila 6 shekels, 
.en: total: 11,611 1/2 female laborer days, 
.en: booked out. 
.en: Deficit: 10 gur, 1 barig 3 ban 1 1/3 sila 4 shekels barley, 
.en: surplus: 4 10 shekels (=1/6) female laborer days. 
.en: Account of Lu-sa-izu, 
.en: month: “Bricks cast in moulds” (month 2), 
.en: year following “Harši was destroyed” (Amar-Suen 1).

r.en: enuru: 
r.en: A man a snake struck, a scorpion struck, a rabid dog struck, 
r.en: their spittle gave. 
r.en: Asarluḫi 
r.en: to his father Enki a messenger sends: 
r.en: “My father, a man a snake struck, a scorpion struck, a rabid dog struck,
r.en: their spittle gave; 
r.en: what to do about it, I don't know.” 
r.en: “My son, what don't you know? 
.en: What can I add? 
r.en: His silver ala is purified; 
r.en: once to the water the incantation is given, 
r.en: the water the ‘foreigner’ made to drink, 
r.en: may the spittle on its own go out!” 
r.en: A man by a snake bitten: the water the ‘foreigner’ is to be given to drink. 
r.en: 2 1/2 mana 4 shekels less 15 grains silver, 
r.en: remainder of the account, 
r.en: against Ḫubidam, the trade agent, 
r.en: exists; 
r.en: it is to be repaid; 
r.en: via Ki-tuš-lu, the scribe, 
r.en: and Sipa-inim-gina; 
r.en: year following: “For the 3rd time Simurrum was destroyed.”

r.en: It was (the case) that the daughter of Dada did not escape. 
r.en: The governor 
r.en: (about this) Ipa’e asked. 
r.en: “She escaped,” (Ipa’e) told him. 
r.en: (But) from that place she did not move, she stayed there. 
r.en: (With) the governor 
r.en: his statement did (Ipa’e) not put in order;

r.en: the estate overseer

r.en: To my lord 
r.en: say 
r.en: what Ilī-ištakal says: 
r.en: “1 2-wheeled transport wagon 
r.en: give out to me,” I said to him, 
r.en: but he did not give to me; 
r.en: as to his sending out, 
r.en: in Kibabbara, 
r.en: in the house of Bazizi, 
.en: 1 2-wheeled transport wagon 
.en: is available; 
.en: my own man saw it! 
.en: After his (my lord’s) messenger 
.en: has returned, 
r.en: may he (my lord) have him (Bazizi) give it to me! 
r.en: His (my lord’s) strong servant am I; 
r.en: come now, may my gut be happy! 
r.en: The written document of this case 
r.en: should be before him (Bazizi)! 
r.en: In this way to his mind 
r.en: it should this be made clear! 
r.en: Then I will myself make his (my lord’s) gut happy!

.en: when they have reached the place of rations,

.en: the ration of a man with a child was established as triple;
.en: the ration of a single man was established as single;
.en: but the ration of Martu, though being single, was also established as double.
.en: Martu (went home) to his own mother,
.en: He entered the house before her and spoke to her:
.en: "In my city I am among my friends and they all have already married wives;
.en: I am there among my mates, and they all have already married wives.
.en: Unlike my friends in my city I am single,
.en: I am single and I have no children.
.en: Yet the imposed share exceeds that of my friends;
.en: over and above that of my mates, I received half of theirs."

r.en: the spike;

.en: Sin was harvesting, 
r.en: Šamaš was gathering together.

r.en: did enter 
r.en: the seed.

r.en: Holy An, the great words of his mouth are not to be abrogated. 
r.en: The great gods bow down to him, like a curved staff, in approval of and in prayer to him.  
r.en: What you command is just. (Like) what a prince or lord has uttered, what you have commanded is obeyed. 
r.en: An, your lofty command takes precedence, who would say No to you? 
r.en: Father of the gods, your word, the foundation of heaven and earth, no god fails to heed it.  
r.en: Lord, you are the leader who takes only his own counsel, what should be our counsel? 
r.en: Grant your strength to the maiden Ištar, whom you have loved.   
r.en: Your reliable approval, weighty as heaven, make known (to her) in our assembly.  
r.en: Give to the mistress, whom you have loved, your combined divine powers.   
.en: Let Kišar truly be the spouse equal with you, may she rise to the (equivalent) authority of your name.  
.en: Moreover, in addition let her carry out herself the decrees of Enlil and Enki.    
.en: When she alone has taken hold of the nose-rope of heaven and earth, she shall be our strength! 
.en: For An, the pleasant conversation produced happiness.
.en: He in his goodness of heart treated holy Inanna well.   
.en: The commands of my Anu-ship are the complex fundament(?) of heaven which cannot be equaled.  
.en: My fixed boundaries whose exteriors are fearsome and know no approaching, 
.en: I am Anšar/Anu, the king's helper, do take hold of their band.   
.en: Do take for yourself the entire extent of their territory, exercise alone the ruling of them!
.en: Come, rise up to my dais of kingship and dwell in the heights!
.en: Corresponding to my called name, may Exalted Kišar/Antu be your called name! 
.en: My faithful vizier, whose lips are prized, who is aware of my secrets, 
.en: Ninšubur, my fitting vizier, shall exercise the status of father with you. 
.en: May he (standing) before you constantly present auspicious words from (every) god and goddess. 
.en: At the eternal foundation of heaven and earth and by the enduring designs of the gods,  
.en: when, in the beginning, Anu, Enlil and Ea allotted the shares, 
r.en: for the two gods, the watchmen of heaven and netherworld, the ones who open the door of Anu,
r.en: for moon-god and sun-god the night and day were made in equal parts, 
r.en: and from the bottom of heaven to the top of heaven they assign them their tasks: 
r.en: to keep all the stars of heaven on course as in a furrow, 
r.en: to make the leading gods keep to their paths like oxen. 
r.en: Up into that place, Inanna, rise to the rulership of them all! 
r.en: Lady, you be the brightest of them, so may they call you Ištar of the Stars!  
r.en: May your high position (relative to them) alternate between the two sides (east and west) triumphantly!
r.en: May your splendor be as abundant as that of the moon and sun in (their) watches. 
.en: May the flaring glow of your torch shine high in the sky!  
.en: May the people marvel at you as one for whom among the gods there is none to check up on her.
.en: After the lord had bestowed (these) great powers upon the daughter of Sîn, 
.en: he did not keep her away from the shrine Eanna, her sacred chamber.
.en: After king Anu had bestowed the great powers upon her, 
.en: they presented to her the shrine Eanna, her sacred chamber. 
.en: He covered her figure with the ceremonial garment of Anu-hood, the brilliant splendor of Sîn.
.en: He made her appear like the day with superb ornaments, the ornaments of divinity. 
.en: He enhanced her arm with the scepter of kingship, the fierce wood (staff), the unsparing weapon.   
.en: A glorious crown which is like (that on) the head of Nanna he set (firmly) upon her head.  
.en: O Hierodule, my important decisions, divine powers which could not be asked for (by anyone else) I have assigned to you. 
.en: Like me, may Enlil, king of all the lands, treat you well!  
.en: Because of this Lord Nunamnira became happy, his liver surged with joy.

r.en: May the arrowhead that pierces lungs and heart go back and forth like a shuttle. 
r.en: Inanna, after you have made fighting and battle flip about(?) like a skip-rope, 
r.en: O lady of battle, make them clash together like a ball(?) and driving stick. 
r.en: Goddess of contention, make battle be pursued like puppets=dolls being manipulated. 
r.en: Lady, at the place of clashing of weapons, strike with chaos like the banging down of astragals. 
r.en: Inanna, when like an overwhelming storm you are consolidating the contingents of battle, 
r.en: when you demonstrate your great ability with the divine mace, the double-headed ax, the big sword and arrows,  
r.en: when you put on the fierce armor, let the deluge rage. 
r.en: When you make ready your bow/throw-stick(?) and shield of battle, may the storms whirl about for you. 
.en: May your raging divine weapon strike the evil person with lightning like (the plague god) Erra. 
.en: Lady, at the place of clashing of weapons and planting of standards, no one can get away from the opening of your arms. 
.en: My daughter, wherever it is pleasing to you to extend upwards, to extend downwards, to pull taut or to loosen, 
.en: Having no limits at the place where destinies are decided, your pronouncements are indeed as great as my pronouncements. 
.en: At festivals, offerings, banquets, prostration(?), making obeisance, and invoking the name (of the god), 
.en: a human being whose god has gotten very angry with him, whose goddess has become soured/jealous towards him, 
.en: as long as he does not seek out the place of reconciliation with your divinity, no god will be agreeable to his petition. 
.en: At my city, the mountain of Sumer and Akkad, the shade of the world quarters, 
r.en: at Duranki, the bond of heaven and earth, the foundation of all constructed settlements,  
r.en: at my royal dais reposing like a horned bull (or elephant?) at the obeisances of the gods,

r.en: the sanctuary, the relaxing dwelling place which is called by my name, 
r.en: may your ladyship also be manifested in that place, may your name be called Queen of Nippur!

r.en: the craftsman of the centerpoint of the Ekur temple, discoverer of advice and planning, the finest oil, 
r.en: let be your guardian be he against whom your wrath was great and whom your divine fury has overcome. 
r.en: May wise Nin-imma'imma cool your heart with pleasant conversations.

.en: (Possessor of) beautiful features, beloved spouse of Nunbaršegunu (Nisaba) 
.en: Man with a great name, father-in-law of Great Mountain Enlil 
.en: Junior saga functionary, wise one, examiner(?) and ... of both heaven and earth 
.en: Who received the tribute of the gods, and disseminates his (Enlil's?) word about the abundance of(?) distant mountains and seas 
.en: Wise one who is clad in the control/superimposition of(!?) the supreme cosmic powers of rulership(?) 
.en: (Possessor) of a mind broadly “squeezed” (of every potential idea?), grasping the holy plans of the temple of Eridu 
.en: Haya, he of the pure šuluh rites of the watery deep, fastened to(?) the ba garment 
.en: Indagara, saga functionary, in heaven and the netherworld (he is) the mouth-opener (ritual practitioner) of the gods 
.en: Who knows the contents of esoteric tablets, the skillfully acting one of the great gods 
.en: The one who fixes in place the emblems set (upon) a wood(en pole)(?), caretaker(?) of the ... site of the land 
.en: (As well as?) the kišutag shrines, and the verdant(?) sanctum for Anšar and Great Mountain (Enlil) 
.en: Supreme one who raises the head, who is agreeable to his (Enki's) command in shrine Abzu 
.en: Caretaker who requisitions pure daily rations (for?) the temples of the gods 
.en: Without Kusu and Indagara the sky would not be pure, the earth would not be clean 
.en: The one who dines extensively in the supreme dining hall/sanctum of An and Enlil 
.en: The one whose pure face(?) is seen by lord Nudimmud/has seen lord Nudimmud(?) 
.en: Who holds the pure bronze vessel/mirror(?) that gladdens the heart and improves/beautifies(?) the back/liver 
.en: My king, I want to praise your greatness in song 
r.en: Haya, I want to constantly discover your greatness as a treasure 
r.en: Who is like you among the gods in being suited for the pure cosmic powers? 
r.en: Your beloved spouse, the young woman Nisaba, the great lady/"elder sister"(?) of ladies 
r.en: Her womb gave birth to(?) Ninlil, the supreme spouse of Nunamnir 
r.en: She who has raised her head in the tent enclosure/at the dais of the Ekur temple, she is able to approach(?) towards heaven 
r.en: She singly exercises the queenship of the gods (as) a god that has no rival 
r.en: You, the great breed bull that finds true counsel, who constantly inquires after the gods 
r.en: Haya, who gives out the cosmic powers and assigns work, you are the one who makes (others?) familiar with(?) the shrine 
r.en: Enki bestowed his incantations of life to you in shrine Abzu 
.en: You install the en priestess in the gipar cloister, you put in place (its) caretaking(?) 
.en: For the shepherd of the homeland, you take hold of the supreme scepter of(?) distant time for his hand 
.en: Haya, god of the homeland, you are the one who listens to the arazu prayer of the many people 
.en: You (among the?) great gods take hold of/settle(?) the broad population for his hand 
.en: After Enki comes forth from the Abzu 
.en: Haya, he shall measure/assign(?) its greatness for you 
.en: The one(s) who are in the midst of the homeland(?) shall raise their necks towards heaven 
.en: Its people will pass the time rejoicing 
.en: You will compel its many people to rejoice as in ancient times 
.en: You establish festivals (in) the temples of the great gods and therefore release joy 
.en: The foremost among the gods(?), when he ... the great lots that sustain/finish(?) the land/people 
.en: For the sake of the king, look faithfully towards him (with) your beautiful face that is filled with/surpassing with(?) life 
.en: For prince Rīm-Sîn, faithfully establish a most joyous reign of distant duration 
.en: Enter this name on the tablet of life, which is never to be altered

en: When like the storm you howl, 
en: the foreign lands, open reeds ablaze, mountains trembling like reeds, 
en: in the houses of the foreign lands watching, 
en: Tidnum well marveled. 
en: Like Utu, your terror radiates in battle. 
en: Like Nergal, your mace drools in death 
en: your lance reaches into the blood of the Land. 
en: The great door of the city are you, the great wall of the Land are you! 
en: A net piled up over heaven and earth are you, lead-jenny positioned with Sumer are you, 
en: May your ... call in abundance! 
en: May the words of Enlil, enormous things, create shade on your head! 
en: May the loving heart Inanna never abandon you!” 
en: After Ninazu had called ... blessings again and again, 
en: he let ewes goodly produce endless lambs, 
en: let jennies goodly produce endless kids, 
en: let white cows set up calves, 
en: then before Nanna in his E-temen-ni-guru he enters with them, 
en: head held high in the most fitting house of the the royal household, in its royal offering place, the silver place. 
en: His king Ašimbabbar casts a joyous glance at him, 
en: for Šulgi, the good shepherd of Sumer, decreed a fate: 
en: “Hero, lord, mighty one of the foreign lands, right arm of the Land, 
en: you have achieved victory for me, have carried out the commandeds. 
en: The houses of the rebel lands that I have cursed you have reduced to ruin mounds. 
en: May you never grow weary of perfecting the divine powers for me every month at new moon! 
en: Like Ašnan, may your name be as sweet in the mouth of the Land and in the mouths of all the countries! 
en: May silver Ningal, lady of the Enunna, like the wooden frame of a waterskin spread out her lap for you! 
en: Thus did Suen decree a good fate. 
en: In the Egal-maḫ of Ninegal, he took his seat on the silver throne. 
en: The Ištaran of Sumer, omniscient from the womb, 
en: renders the judgments of the Land in due order, 
en: makes decisions for the Land in due order 
en: lets no strong man wrong the weak, 
en: lets mother speak sweetly to her child 
en: lets child answer truthfully to his father. 
en: Sumer is filled with abundance, 
en: Ur prolonged in splendor, 
en: ... establishes. 
en: Because the king exulted in his triumph and let his might radiate, 
en: his heroism set well, 
en: made the rebellious lands bow, 
en: made our city Ur raise neck in prosperity; 
en: king, adorned with a face of colorful lapis, son of Enlil; 
en: lifting up head to heaven in broad crown, 
en: with An in his lofty place taking counsel, sitting with Uraš on a big throne, 
en: manth and passing days making the Land of Sumer and all the foreign lands play joyously— 
en: praise be to Lord Ašimbabbar! 
en: praise be to Nisaba!

n: whom to her master
n: she has born,
n: will be a child equal to a free child;
n: his (share of the) estate shall be made good.
n: If
n: a man

n: has not born him a child,

n: has born him a child,

n: grain ration, oil ration,
n: and wool ration

n: that she has born to him

n: however long his wife
n: is alive,
n: the prostitute
n: with the equal-ranking wife
n: shall not reside in the house.

n: a man’s
n: equal-ranking wife

n: or she has become paralyzed,
n: she shall not be evicted from the house;
n: her husband
n: a 2nd wife
n: may marry;
n: the later wife must

n: support.
n: If

n: has entered,
n: and he has made the betrothal gift,
n: and afterward
n: they have evicted him
n: and his wife to his friend
n: they have given,

n: which he brought

n: that wife his friend
n: shall not marry.
n: If
n: a young man having a wife
n: a prostitute in the town square
n: has had,
n: and that to that prostitute
n: he should not return
n: the judges have told him,
n: and afterwards his equal-ranking wife
n: he has divorced,
n: when he has paid her his divorce money,
n: he may not marry that prostitute.
n: If
n: a father while living
n: to a son favored in his eyes
n: has presented a gift
n: and has written him a sealed document,
n: after the father has died,
n: the heirs
n: shall divide the father’s estate,
n: but they shall not divide the (already) allotted share;

n: they shall not say ... .

n: he has married a wife,
n: after the father has died
n: the heirs

n: they(?) shall make,
n: and the betrothal gift ...
n: they shall ...
n: If
n: about a man’s daughter,
n: who was unmarried, ‘You had sexual relations,’
n: another man has said,
n: when that she had not had sexual relations
n: she has proved,
n: he shall pay 10 shekels of silver.
n: If
n: a man

r.en: Yadiḫi-ilī 
r.en: son of Zankana-x.
r.en: It was time to decide destinies in heaven and on earth, 
r.en: Lagash had raised the head towards heaven in large ‘me’, 
r.en: Enlil looked righteously upon lord Ningirsu. 
r.en: Did the ‘nig2-ul’ not emerge in our city? 
r.en: The ‘heart’, did it not return to its banks? 
r.en: The ‘heart’ of Enlil, did it not return to its banks? 
r.en: The ‘heart’, did it not return to its banks? 
r.en: The flood, did it not twinkle? Frightening (all). 
r.en: The ‘heart’ of Enlil, it is the river Tigris, did it not bring sweet water? 
.en: To the house its king spoke: 
.en: “I will make the ‘me’ of Eninnu emerge in heaven and on earth. 
.en: The governor is wise, he shall pay attention. 
.en: He shall enlarge big things. 
.en: He shall straighten the horns of perfect oxen, perfect goats.” 
.en: The brick of deciding destinies lifted the head towards him, 
.en: to build the shiny house it raised its neck towards him. 
.en: It was then, in a ‘dark goat’, that towards his king, 
.en: on the lord Ningirsu, Gudea looked. 
.en: “Build his house!,” he ordered him. 
.en: On Eninnu, whose ‘me’ is very large, 
.en: he (Ningirsu) directed his (Gudea’s) eye there. 
.en: Gudea, his ‘heart’ is distant, 
.en: counseled about the message: 
.en: “Let me, let me tell it to her, let me, let me tell it to her, 
.en: may she stand by me in this case. 
.en: I am the shepherd, princeliness was given to me. 
.en: Of what my ‘dark goat’ has revealed to me, 
.en: its ‘heart’ I did not know. 
.en: Let me bring my dream to her, to my mother. 
.en: My dream-interpreter, knowing ‘ku3’ on her own, 
.en: Nanše, my divine sister from Siraran, 
.en: may she make its meaning visible for me.” 
.en: Did he not set foot on his barge? 
.en: Towards Nina, her city, on Ininadua, he directed the barge, 
.en: he is breaking the waves of Ideḫula. 
.en: After reaching Bagara—house hanging over the river, 
.en: he sacrificed bread, he poured out cold water, 
.en: he went to the king of Bagara, and prayed to him: 
.en: “Hero, charging lion, having no rival, 
.en: Ningirsu, boisterous in the Apsû, 
.en: being noble in Nippur. 
.en: Hero, you spoke to me, let me do it right for you, 
.en: Ningirsu, let me build your house for you, 
.en: let me make the ‘me’ perfect for you. 
.en: Your sister, child born to Eridu, 
.en: hero in her own right, lady-dream-interpreter of the gods, 
.en: Nanše, my divine sister from Siraran, 
.en: may she place the path for me.” 
.en: His (Gudea’s) prayer was being heard. 
.en: From Gudea, his offering and his prayer, his king, 
.en: the lord Ningirsu, received from him. 
.en: In the House of Bagara he celebrated the week-festival. 
.en: The governor set up his bed in the house of Gatumdu. 
.en: He sacrificed bread, he poured out cold water. 
.en: He went to Shiny-Gatumdu, 
.en: (and then) he is saying an offering(!) to her: 
.en: “My lady, child born by shiny An,

en: Shrine-Eninnu it is placed in the hand of the x of heaven. 
en: The governor built the house, he made it grow, 
en: he made it grow like a large mountain, 
en: he placed the very large mast, the foundation, its Abzu, in the ground. 
en: With Enki, in E'angurraka, 
en: he counseled with him there. 
en: The foundation, ‘a hero in heaven’, he seized in the house; 
en: it drinks water at the drinking place of the gods. 
en: He made Eninnu firm as a mast. 
en: He built its Abgal. 
en: He planted sweet Asal trees in his city, 
en: he stretched out their shadow. 
en: He placed the ‘multitude-eraser’, like a great sign, with Lagash 
en: He placed it in Šugalam, its terrible place, 
en: Having goosebumps in Baragirnunna, the place of rendering justice. 
en: The provider for Lagash raises the arm like a great ox. 
en: His large stones brought in their blocks, 
en: he brought them in a single year, he worked them in a single year, 
en: he did not let two, three days pass for them, 
en: one each day’s work he erected, 
en: on the seventh day he seized them in the house. 
en: A stone on its side he laid down as a basin, 
en: he formed it with incense, 
en: he placed them in the house. 
en: His stone erected in the mighty courtyard, 
en: ‘the stela, king filling the courtyard, 
en: Lord Ningirsu made Gudea 
en: known from Girnun,’ 
en: as name of that stone he named. 
en: His stone erected in Kasurra, 
en: ‘the king, flood of Enlil, 
en: no-haver of opponent, 
en: Lord Ningirsu, on Gudea 
en: looked righteously,’ 
en: as name of that stone he named. 
en: His stone erected in front of the rising sun, 
en: ‘the King, roaring storm of Enlil, 
en: lord no-haver of rival, 
en: Lord Ningirsu, Gudea, 
en: in his shiny ‘heart’ called him,’ 
en: as name of that stone he named. 
en: His stone erected in front of Šugalam, 
en: ‘by the name of his king the mountains tremble, 
en: Lord Ningirsu, Gudea, 
en: his throne he made firm,’ 
en: as name of that stone he named. 
en: His stone erected in front of E'uruagaka: 
en: ‘lord Ningirsu, for Gudea, 
en: decided a sweet destiny,’ 
en: as name of that stone he named. 
en: His stone erected in Baba’s back-room, 
en: ‘Eninnu, knowing the face of An, 
en: Baba, life of Gudea,’ 
en: as name of that stone he named. 
en: He build the house of his king with righteousness. 
en: The righteous shepherd Gudea made it grow together with heaven and earth. 
en: Raising the crown like the new moon, 
en: its name until the middle of the mountain 
en: he made emerge. 
en: Gudea made Ningirsu’s house 
en: go out from the cloud like Utu, 
en: made it grow like a mountain of Lapis, 
en: like a white alabaster mountain, 
en: made it stand to be admired. 
en: Its ‘dubla’ stood (there) like an aurochs, 
en: its dragons lay (there) like lions on their paws. 
en: Its Gigun grows in a pure place like the Abzu, 
en: Its sign like the shiny ibex of Abzu, 
en: he made shine the horns, 
en: like the new moon standing in heaven, 
en: Gudea made the house of Ningirsu 
en: stand to be admired. 
en: The ‘dubla’ that stand in the house, 
en: that stand with Abzu Lahama, 
en: The house of standing wood is a wave (in) the mighty marsh into which snakes have dived. 
en: Its stretched out mouth, 
en: it is the terror of the x-heaven. 
en: The ‘covered house’ of the house is a light floating in the middle of the heavens. 
en: (Going out) from the gate, ‘entrance of the king’, 
en: it is an eagle gazing at an aurochs. 
en: The arrow leaning against the gate, 
en: it is the rainbow leaning against heaven. 
en: Its upper lintel, it is Eninnu coiled up, the roaring storm. 
en: Its frightening eyebrows, 
en: it is the admiring face of the gods. 
en: The house, his white flood returning, 
en: it is a lapis mountain firmly moored in heaven and earth. 
en: They prepare the meal in the great sanctuary, 
en: it is gold bowls filled with honney and wine, 
en: standing under the heaven. 
en: The built the bed-room, 
en: it is the shiny ‘mes’ tree of Abzu (competing) with innumerable mountains, 
en: carrying fruit. 
en: He built, and after he had finished it, 
en: it is the ‘heart’ of the gods, returned to its banks. 
en: The righteous shepherd Gudea has learned big (things), 
en: and he will perform big (things). 
en: At the war-door of the inner room, where the weapon hang, 
en: Sagar, the hero, the six headed ram, 
en: he seizes there. 
en: At the frightening place facing the city, 
en: the seven heroes he seizes there. 
en: At Šugalam, the gate of radiance, 
en: the dragon and the date palm he seizes there. 
en: At Igi'u'e, the place of deciding destinies, 
en: the emblem of Utu, the head of a bison, 
en: he places there. 
en: At Kasur, the cherished, 
en: a lion, the fear of the gods, 
en: he seizes there. 
en: At Tarsirsir, the place of instructions, 
en: (the metal) ‘friend of heaven’ and copper, 
en: he seizes there. 
en: At the inner room of Baba, place of council, 
en: Magilum and Gualim (bison) 
en: he seizes there. 
en: Because they are dead warriors, 
en: he placed their mouths at the libation place, 
en: (and) their names, in the midst of the gods, 
en: Gudea, governor of Lagash, 
en: made them emerge. 
en: The cedar doors standing in the house, 
en: it is Iškur roaring from heaven. 
en: Eninnu, its lock, a bison(?), 
en: its pivots, a lion; 
en: from its bolt, Muššatur (and) Mušhuš 
en: stretch out the tongue against an aurochs. 
en: The lintels leaning on the door, 
en: it is a young lioness, whose young ones rest on its paws. 
en: They fastened the shiny roof nail in the house, 
en: it is a dragon laying hand on a man. 
en: They stretched out the shiny (measuring) rope in the door, 
en: it is the shiny water snake of Abzu, dividing (things). 
en: Keš and Aratta give instructions at the tying (together) of the house: 
en: the tying together, it is a terrible lion, 
en: gazing at the land, 
en: the lonely wanderer cannot pass. 
en: The fear of Eninnu, on all the lands, 
en: like a garment, it covered. 
en: The house, founded by Anu with purified silver, 
en: decorated with good perfume, 
en: rising in heavenly brilliance, like the moon. 
en: The face of the house is a large mountain leaning on earth, 
en: its inside is a polyphonic song, 
en: its outside is a mighty house of abundance rising in heaven. 
en: Its outer throne room, 
en: the place of rendering the justice of Anunna, 
en: from its water throughs are words of prayer, 
en: with its food rations are the abundance of the gods. 
en: The signs placed with the house, 
en: it is Anzu spreading his wings in Kurmuš. 
en: The clay of Eninnu, mixed clay, 
en: is a flood draining(?) from the plain. 
en: Its king, Lord Ningirsu, 
en: chose it in his shiny ‘heart’, 
en: he poured it on top like good incense. 
en: Gudea, in the brilliance of heaven, 
en: decorated it. 
en: From the cow pen, 
en: oil deliveries, milk deliveries, 
en: From the mighty oven, 
en: large cakes, large croissants(!?). 
en: The Girpana, 
en: feeding oxen, feeding sheep. 
en: The provisions place, sustaining the uzga. 
en: The wine-cellar(?) 
en: (called) ‘mountain dripping with wine’. 
en: From the brewery, 
en: (called) ‘Tigris is being water in its might’. 
en: In the treasury, precious stones, silver, tin. 
en: The coach house, 
en: (called) ‘mountain standing on the ground’. 
en: The inner room of haprs, (called) ‘ox roaring princely’. 
en: The courtyard, shiny prayers, ‘sim’ and ‘ala’ (sounds). 
en: The stone basin sleeping in the house, 
en: it is a mountain sleeping in full flowering. 
en: The tin basin, siding with the storeroom, 
en: it is the light lifting the distant gaze to the mountain. 
en: The garden of the black plain placed with the house, 
en: it is the frightening place grown together with ‘mountain driping with wine’. 
en: The seven stones seized by the house, 
en: are things counselling with its king. 
en: The house of funerary offerings, 
en: is a pure thing, instructed by Abzu. 
en: The fragrant stones standing in the house, 
en: it is the house of the purification priests never lacking water. 
en: The high battlements 
en: where pigeons dwell, 
en: it is Eridu, built in abundance(?). 
en: Eninnu [...] the doves, 
en: it is a shade of large leaves, a sweet shadow. 
en: Buru-birds shrieking, 
en: it is the Ekur of Enlil in a festival. 
en: The big fear of the house 
en: rests on the land. 
en: Its praise 
en: reaches the mountains. 
en: The fear of Eninnu covers all the lands like a garment. 
en: The house (was) built in joy by its king. 
en: Ningešzida 
en: built it on a big place. 
en: Gudea, governor of Lagash, 
en: placed its foundation. 
en: Temple--going out in the land, 
en: standing outside in the dust like a big ox, 
en: like the moon pleasurably 
en: filling the assembly, 
en: like a green mountain 
en: clad in joy, 
en:--standing to be admired. 
en: For the restoration of Eninnu 
en: Ningirsu be praised! 
en: The building of the house of Ningirsu, 
en: this is the middle of the praise. 
r.en: House, mooring post of the Land,
r.en: grown up from earth to heaven,
r.en: Eninnu, the good Brick for which Enlil has made a favorable firm promise,
r.en: green mountain range, standing to be admired,
r.en: standing out above all the lands.
r.en: The House, being a great mountain, bordered on heaven,
r.en: being the sun, it filled mid-heaven with light,
r.en: being Eninnu, the White Thunderbird,
r.en: it (attacked) the mountain with spread wings.
.en: The people have all been settled (again), and the Land has gone home,
.en: (but) the Anunna gods are all standing in admiration.
.en: The ruler, who is wise, is knowledgeable,
.en: kisses the ground over and over before the divinities;
.en: with rites and prayer, in submission, he touches the ground;
.en: the ruler, the (personal) god of his city, says a prayer.
.en: For the bread-consuming House he added more bread,
.en: for the supper in need of mutton he added more sheep.
.en: As if it were for the abundance of vast midheaven,
.en: in front (of the House) he set up jars in a row.
.en: He went to the Anunna gods,
.en: prayed to them: “O all you Anunna gods who are admiring (what) the Land of Lagaš (achieved),
.en: protectors of all the countries, whose command, a torrent of water,
.en: will make the one who (would try to) stem it founder,
.en: (but) who to the worthy man upon whom they looked
.en: have given a long life,
.en: I, the shepherd, built the House, and my master will enter his House—
.en: would you, O Anunna gods, say a blessing on my behalf?”
.en: The true shepherd Gudea
.en: is wise and able, too, to realize things.
.en: His friendly guardian walks in front of him,
.en: and his friendly protecting genius is following him,
.en: (and so) to his master for the House of yore, the old House, his (former) abode,
.en: to the lord Ningirsu Gudea
.en: made great gifts.
.en: He went into Eninnu, to the lord,
.en: prayed to him:
.en: “My master Ningirsu,
.en: lord who has turned back the fierce waters,
.en: lord whose command takes precedence,
.en: Enlil’s male child, warrior, you spoke to me,
.en: and I did faithfully obey you.
.en: Ningirsu, I built you your House,
.en: may you enter it in joy.”
.en: (And he added) “My Baba, I erected your women’s quarters for you,
.en: move in in comfort.”
.en: His call was heard,
.en: the warrior accepted from Gudea, the lord Ningirsu
.en: accepted from him, prayer and rite.
.en: (Meanwhile) the year had ended, the month had been completed,
.en: the new year had appeared in the sky,
.en: the month “had entered its house,”
.en: and of that month the third day had passed:
.en: (Then) Ningirsu had arrived from Eridu,
.en: (and) the most beautiful moonlight shone
.en: illuminating the Land; Eninnu with the (new-)born moon (god)
.en: vied.
.en: Gudea made a paste with carnelian and lapis lazuli,
.en: he put it in the corners
.en: and sprinkled abundant oil on the floor.
.en: He bade the builders, the workmen,
.en: leave the House.
.en: Syrup, butter oil, wine, sour milk,
.en: gipar-fruit, fig-cakes
.en: topped with cheese,
.en: dates in clusters(?), small grapes,
.en: (all) things untouched by fire,
.en: (to prepare) food for the gods,
.en: he used syrup and butter.
.en: From the moment when the sun rose in the good sky,
.en: Gudea, from early morning
.en: till supper (time) passed to and fro.
.en: Asari saw to it that the House was all right,
.en: Nin-mada gave advice,
.en: king Enki provided oracular messages.
.en: Nin-duba, foremost lustration priest of Eridu,
.en: filled (the House) with incense,
.en: the lady of precious rites, Nanše, who knows the words of sacred songs, put them to music for the House.
.en: She “sheared” the black ewes (of the sky),
.en: and of the cow-of-heaven
.en: she milked the udder,
.en: while with (brooms of) tamarisk and ...,
.en: they were cleaning Eninnu
.en: until they had polished it to perfection.
.en: The ruler made the (whole) city kneel down,
.en: he made the Land prostrate itself.
.en: He leveled what was high, refused (to listen to) chance utterances,
.en: “spittle” (of sorcery) was removed from the daggers.
.en: In the city (only) the mother of a sick person
.en: administered a potion—the wild animals, creatures of the steppe,
.en: all had crouched together.
.en: Lion, lioness(?) and the “dragon of the steppe”
.en: enjoyed sweet sleep.
.en: Rites (had made) the day (go by), prayers the night,
.en: the early morning (had) the moonlight (caused to fade)—
.en: was the master (of the House) on his way?
.en: (Yea,) the warrior Ningirsu was entering (his) House.
.en: The master of the House had come to it
.en: like an eagle catching sight of an aurochs.
.en: When the warrior was entering his House,
en: he was a storm roaring towards battle,
en: Ningirsu went about his House,
en: and it was (just as) in the Abzu sanctuary when a festival is going on.
en: The owner indeed came out of his House (again),
en: and he was (like) the sun god rising above the land of Lagaš.
en: When Baba went to her women’s quarters
en: she was (like) a respectful woman caring for her house;
en: when she entered her bedroom
en: she was (like) the Tigris at high waters,
en: when she sat down in ...
en: she was the lady, daughter of bright An, a green garden bearing fruit.
en: The day was about to rise, firm promise had been fulfilled,
en: Baba had entered her women’s quarters—
en: that meant) abundance for the land of Lagaš.
en: The day dawned, the sungod of Lagaš lifted his head over the Land.
en: Fattened oxen and sheep were taken to the House,
en: (Gudea) set up a jar in the open air, poured much wine into it.
en: The Anunna gods of the land of Lagaš were installed around the lord Ningirsu.
en: (Gudea) performed the purification of the House in the most attentive way,
en: and he took care of portents.
en: Wine was poured from the big jar
en: while Eninnu amassed ...
en: Nin-duba caused the sanctuary to be full of clatter and noise,
en: and with fresh bread, milk of hinds
en: available day and night,
en: the noble one, the beloved child of Enlil, the warrior Ningirsu.
en: he rouses from sleep.
en: He (Ningirsu) proudly looks around, very sure of himself,
en: (and) his ..., functionaries, (and) ...
en: he lines up (to be assigned functions) for the sanctuary Eninnu.
en: That he (Ig-alim) might guide the hand of the righteous one
en: and force the evil-doer’s neck into a neck stock,
en: that he might keep the House safe, keep it in harmony,
en: that he might give instructions to his city (and) the sanctuaries of Girsu,
en: that he might establish a throne of firm promise,
en: hand over a sceptre for long days,
en: that he might make the shepherd called by Ningirsu
en: lift high the head as if it wore a blue crown,
en: that the “skin-clad,” the “linen-clad,” and the “covered head”
en: he might appoint to (their) offices in the courtyard of Eninnu—
en: the Great Door, the Pole of Girnun, the chief bailiff of Girsu,
en: his beloved son Ig-alim,
en: he (Gudea) brings along with himself (and introduces) to the lord Ningusu.
en: That he (Šul-šaga) might keep the House clean, let hands always be washed,
en: have clean hands serve water to the lord,
en: that he might pour beer into bowls, wine into jars,
en: that in (Eninnu’s) brewery, the “house (with) the clean arms,”
en: emmer beer like the waters (of) Papsir
en: might bubble,
en: that unblemished oxen and goats and grain-fed sheep,
en: fresh bread, and milk of hinds
en: be available day and night, that the noble one,
en: Enlil’s beloved son, the warrior Ningirsu,
en: might rise from sleep ... —
en: the lord of the most careful hand-washing, the first-bom son of Eninnu,
en: Šul-šaga, to Ningirsu
en: he (Gudea) brings along with himself (and introduces).
en: That the seven-headed club might be held (firmly) in hand,
en: that the (“King who makes the mountain tremble") might keep open the door-wings of the Ankar house, the Battle gate,
en: that he might cause the dagger blades, the mace “dead man,” the “floodstorm weapon,”
en: the “Bitter one,” (all of them) battle tools,
en: exactly to hit their targets,
en: all of Enlil’s enemies’ lands
en: that he might inundate—
en: the warrior “Mow-down-a-myriad” who in battle subdues all the lands,
en: the mighty general of Eninnu,
en: the falcon for the rebel land,
en: “King who makes the mountain tremble,” his general,
en: he (Gudea) brings along with himself (and introduces) to Ningirsu.
en: After the heavenly mace “dead man” like a fierce storm
en: has roared against the mountain,
en: (being) the “Mow-down-a-myriad,” the floodstorm of battle,
en: the cudgel of the rebel land,
en: after the lord has frowned at the rebels, the mountain,
en: and hurled at it his furious words,
en: having carried away its wits, that he ...—
en: the lord’s second general who is (called)
en: “The-land-is-but-a-swallow-in-his-hand.”
en: he (Gudea) brings along with himself (and introduces) to Enlil’s son.
en: That supplications of the land Lagaš
en: might be released,
en: that he (Lugal-sisa) might perform rites and prayers for it, propitious ones,
en: that when the warrior is going to Eridu
en: he might bid farewell,
en: and that, (as a result) when he is returning from Eridu,
en: the throne of the built-up city be firm;
en: that for the life of the true shepherd
en: Gudea
en: hands be placed at the mouth (in prayer)—
en: his adviser,
en: Lugal-sisa, to the lord Ningirsu
en: he (Gudea) brings along with himself (and introduces).
en: Of what had been whispered
en: and what had been said aloud,
en: of whether the one speaking straightforwardly be seen as a partner
en: or whether the one speaking evil might not be seen as such(?)—
en: that the warrior sitting on a pure dais,
en: Ningirsu, might be informed in Eninnu
en: Šakkan-the-...- deer, the messenger of the “good house,” ...
en: to the lord Ningirsu he (Gudea) brings along with himself
en: (and introduces).
en: That he (Kindazi) might clean with water, scrub with soap,
en: that oil from the white stone jars be ...,
en: that he (Ningirsu) on his bedspread with blue flowers
en: might enjoy sweet sleep;
en: his bedroom in his “good house”
en: that he might enter from outside,
en: but) not go out from it (again)—
en: Kindazi, who is the one of the “good house”
en: he (Gudea) brings along with himself (and introduces) to the lord Ningirsu.
en: That the brand-new chariot ... might be yoked up
en: and that a donkey stallion, a lion-summoned-for-running,
en: be included in that donkey(-team);
en: that a slender donkey, one of Eridu,
en: might gallop along with the stallions ...;
en: that they might carry their master Ningirsu in joy—
en: the one roaring like a lion,
en: rising like a floodstorm,
en: Ningirsu’s hurrying bailiff,
en: Ensignun, his donkeyherd,
en: he (Gudea) brings along with himself (and introduces) to the lord Ningirsu.
en: That there might be an abundance of fat and cream,
en: that the white goats, milking goats, and the hind,
en: Ningirsu’s mother,
en: might never cease to provide fat and milk for the sanctuary Eninnu—
en: the Lord Stag, the herdsman of the hinds, to the lord Ningirsu
en: he (Gudea) brings along with himself (and introduces).
en: That the kettle drum(?) of beautiful sound be properly tuned,
en: that Eninnu’s courtyard be full of merriment,
en: that algar and mirītum, the instruments of the “good house,”
en: to the listening warrior,
en: to Ningirsu in Eninnu, offer their best—
en: his beloved musician, the Dragon-of-the-Land,
en: he (Gudea) brings along with himself (and introduces) to the lord Ningirsu.
en: That one might be at ease, body and soul,
en: that tears be dried off the weeping eye,
en: hat anguish be cut off the anguishing heart;
en: that the lord’s heart that rises like the sea,
en: washes away like the Euphrates,
en: that hits like a floodstorm
en: all Enlil’s enemies,
en: that after submerging has returned to its banks, be ...—
en: his harp, the King-with-the-fierce-face,
en: he (Gudea) brings along with himself (and introduces) to the lord Ningirsu
en: His beloved lukur maidens, (creating) plentitude for the myriads,
en: Zazaru,
en: Iškur-pa’e,
en: Ur-agrunta-ea,
en: Ḫegirnuna,
en: Ḫešaga,
en: Zurmu,
en: Zarmu—
en: Baba’s 7 (twin) daughters they are
en: and Ningirsu’s unruly children—
en: with friendly prayers on behalf of Gudea
en: they are standing by the lord Ningirsu.
en: That the vast fields might grow rich,
en: that the ditches and canals of Lagaš
en: be full to the brim,
en: that in the plain befitting its owner,
en: in Gu-edina, the Grain goddess, Bright-and-long, Pure stalk,
en: might proudly look up from her furrow,
en: that after the good fields (of Lagaš) have brought wheat, emmer and all kinds of pulses,
en: enormous grain heaps, the (whole) yield of the land of Lagaš,
en: might be heaped up—
en: Enlil’s surveyor, the farmer of Gu-edina,
en: Gešbar-e, to the lord Ningirsu
en: he (Gudea) brings along with himself (and introduces).
en: About the marshes (of Lagaš), after they had brought forth carp and perch(?),
en: and about the green cane-brakes, after they had produced new shoots of reed—
en: that I, the messenger of Gu-edina,
en: might inform Ningirsu in Eninnu,
en: Lama-inspector-of-the-fisheries-of-Gu-edina
en: he (Gudea) brings along with himself (and introduces) to the lord Ningirsu.
en: That the steppe (as far as it is) a “good” place might be properly advised,
en: the Gu-edina, the “good” steppe,
en: be subject to inspection,
en: that the birds might ...,
en: that their eggs might be in the nest,
en: that they rear their young,
en: that the weaned young of the beasts, as many as there are,
en: the beloved steppe of Ningirsu
en: might not diminish,
en: Dimngal-abzu, the herald of Gu-edina,
en: to the lord Ningirsu along with himself
en: he (Gudea) brings (and introduces).
en: That cities be built, settlements be founded,
en: that the guard-houses of the wall of the Shining City might be built,
en: that its resident constable,
en: (being) the White cedar mace with the enormous head,
en: might stay close to the House—
en: the divine Master of the guard house of the Shining City
en: he (Gudea) brings along with himself (and introduces) to the lord Ningirsu.
en: Enlil had ...,
en: Ninḫursag had looked on it in a friendly way,
en: Enki, king of Eridu, had driven in its foundation boxes.
en: the true lord of a most pure heart, Suen,
en: had in fact seen to it that (Eninnu’s) powers were greater than (the whole of) heaven and earth.
en: Ningirsu had conceived (the House) in (his) heart as a sanctuary from which the seed sprouted,
en: for the (first) Brick of the land of Lagaš Mother Nanše
en: had cared,
en: (but) the god of most reliable progeny
en: (really) did build the House and make its name famous.
en: The mighty steward of Nanše,
en: the brave shepherd of Ningirsu,
en: is wise and able, too, to realize things.
en: For the House, the one who built it,
en: Gudea, ruler
en: of Lagaš,
en: is (now) making presents.
en: The chariot (named) “It subdued the mountain,” which carries terror and has made great awe “ride” on it,
en: its donkey stallion, a merrily neighing wind,
en: which is to be harnessed with the (other) donkeys,
en: the seven-headed club, fierce battle mace,
en: the weapon unbearable for North and South, a cudgel in pitched battle,
en: (and) the “dead man,” the lion-headed weapon of ḫulālu stone,
en: which never turns back before the highlands,
en: the ... 9 standards,
en: the warrior-arm,
en: his bow twanging like a forest of mes trees,
en: his angry arrows whizzing like flashes in battle,

en: stick out the tongue,

en: At that time: If a man
en: has committed murder,
en: that man is to be killed.

en: has acted like a robber, he shall be killed.

en: If

en: by deception
en: another man has worked,
en: and he has plowed it,
en: and a trial has been held regarding it,
en: and it was put to another’s account,
en: that man

en: If

en: per 1 iku of field

en: he shall measure out.
en: If
en: a man to another man
en: a field for cultivation
en: has given,
en: but he did not plow it,
en: and empty land
en: he has left,

en: If
en: a man to another man a field on irrigable land
en: for cultivation
en: has given,
en: per 1 bur3 of field 2 shekels as its interest
en: the field will generate from him.
en: If a man has given to another man a ... field for cultivation,
en: per ... n shekels
en: he shall pay him.
n: If
n: a man has hired oxen or cows for harrowing,
n: for a 2 year’s hire of it
n: he shall measure out to him 8 gur of barley;
n: for the hire of oxen or cows for lead or middle (?),
n: he shall measure out to him 6 gur of barley.
n: If a man has died
n: and has no sons,
n: an umarried daughter
n: shall become his heir.
n: If a man has died,
n: and his daughter ...,
n: she shall inherit the goods of her father’s estate.
n: A younger sister should share the inheritance of the estate,
n: but the father’s subsistance allotments shall be shared by the (estate’s) workers.
n: If a man has put barley into another man’s house,
n: and that house has been broken into,
n: when the owner of the barley has taken an oath,
n: the owner of the house shall replace it.
n: If a man has put barley into another man’s house,
n: and the owner of the house has changed,
: after it has been verified,
: he shall put in for him twice as much barley as was therein.
n: If a man has put barley into another man’s house,
n: per 1 gur barley ... will be its nig2-diri levy.
n: If a man who married a wife
n: has left his wife behind,
n: when she has stayed (waiting) 6 months for him
n: the woman may be married by a husband of her choice.
n: If a man married a wife,
n: and his wife died,
n: the man, until he remarries,
n: his wife’s marriage gifts should be brought to him;
n: but when the man marries a (new) wife,
n: the marriage gifts should return to her people’s household.
n: If a man has died,
n: his wife, until she remarries,
n: the house ...
n: in/of her ... will not be put.
n: If the father has died,
n: ... of his sons
n: will be ...;
n: ... the physical house is the elder brother’s.
n: If an ox has been lost in its cattle pen,
n: the cowherds
n: shall replace it.
n: If a sheep has been lost in its sheepfold,
n: the shepherds
n: shall replace it.
n: If an ox, a sheep, a donkey, or a pig has been lost among the houses or in a well-pit of a city,
n: the district (authorities)
n: shall replace it.
n: If a man has not lost anything,
n: but he has declared: “I have lost something of mine;”
n: when by the district
n: it has been proved,
n: that man shall be killed;
n: the district shall take away his inheritance.
n: The nig2-diri levy for 1 stolen ox is 1 barig;
n: the nig-diri levy for 1 stolen donkey is 3 ban2;
n: the nig-diri levy for 1 stolen sheep is 1 ban2, (due) at the new year.
n: If a man takes another man to court,
n: after he has made him proceed through (court) appearances regarding it for the 3rd time, the suit shall be ended.
n: If in winter
n: a man has hired a 60-gur boat,
n: its nig2-diri levy will be 1 ban2,
n: its hire rate for 1 day will be (blank).
n: If a man has hired a 60-gur boat: for 30 double-miles, its nig2-diri levy will be 3 ban2 per 1 gur;
n: for 20 double-miles its nig2-diri levy will be 2 ban2 per 1 gur;
n: for 10 double-miles the nig2-diri levy will be 1 ban2 per 1 gur.
n: It is of barley; its silver is 1/3rd shekel.
n: 1 day’s wages of a house-builder will be 3 ban2.
n: For a carpenter, leatherworker, reed-mat maker, felt maker, metalsmith, fuller, goldsmith, or stone-cutter,
n: their harvest-time wages will be 3 ban2 each;
n: their winter ones will be 2 ban2 each.
n: The barley for 3 ...-pots will be 1 ban2;
n: the barley for 1 kurdu pot will be 1 ban2;
n: for 1 lahtan pot of 1 gur (capacity) it will be 3 ban2;
n: the barley for 1 oven will be 5 sila3.
n: If a man has broken a leg bone,
n: and a physician has made him well,
n: the silver for that will be 5 shekels.
n: If a man has been mauled by a lion,
n: and a physician has made him well,
n: the silver for that will be 5 shekels.
n: If a physician has taken out a ‘stone,’
n: the silver for that will be 5 shekels.
n: If a physician has healed the eyesight,
n: the silver for that will be 2 shekels.
n: If a physician ... a man,
n: the silver for that will be n shekels.
n: The harvest-time wages of a ... will be 3 ban2;
n: his winter ones will be 2 ban2.
n: The harvest-time wages of the ... persons will be 1 ban2; the nig2-diri levy will be 1 barig;
n: their winter ones will be ... and ... will be the nig2-diri levy.
n: The daily wages of a female weaver when washing (fibers) will be n ban2;
n: the daily wages of a senior female weaver will be 2 ban2;
n: the daily wages of a female weaver of šudur-garments will be 2 ban2.
n: The wages of the ... persons will be 6 sila3 of barley.
n: The wages of the doorman’s helpers ... will be 1 sila3 of barley.
n: If a female tavern-keeper in the harvest season
n: has given 1 beer-jar to a person on credit,
n: at the harvest season 5 ban2 of barley ...,
n: and its nig2-diri levy will be ...;
n: the winter’s will be ...
n: If a man to another man
n: has given 1 gur of barley as a loan,
n: its interest for 1 year shall be 1 barig and 4 ban2 of barley.
n: If a man to another man
n: has given 10 shekels of silver as a loan,
n: its interest for 1 year shall be 2 shekels.
n: If a man to another man ...,
n: and a robber in the house ...,
n: a robber in the house ...,
n: he need not replace it.
n: If a person has fed another person’s child milk,
n: for 3 years her barley shall be 6 gur,
n: her wool 30 minas,
n: and her oil 30 sila3;
n: it is a thing of the office of the nugig-women.
n: The fee per year of a hired wet-nurse shall be 1 shekel.
n: If, during the term of Gutium,
n: a man sold a slave,
n: but that slave someone detained,
n: when the owner of the slave has taken an oath,
n: he may take away the slave.
n: If the man who did the selling has died,
n: (only) when that man’s wife, or his son, or his witness
n: has taken an oath
n: may he take away the slave.
n: During the reign of Ur-Namma, the king of the nig2-diri levy,
n: after he had been elevated by Nanna over the people,
n: at that time, if the man who had sold the slave
n: be he the slave’s owner or ...,
n: or be he its ..., the (relevant) ginabtum-officer
n: if he has not brought in,
n: that man is a thief.
n: If a man has died, his equal-ranking wife should act as the 1st heir in the house.
n: If a man marries the wife of his older brother,
n: he shall be killed.
n: If a slave marries his female owner, he shall be killed.
n: If a man ... another man,
n: ... which is equivalent to the house ...

n: its silver shall be n shekels.
n: If a vacant lot of 1 sar
n: a man has bought, its silver shall be 1 shekel.
n: If 1 sar of a built house
n: a man has rented for ..., he shall pay 1 shekel of silver.
n: A person who erases this inscription and writes his own name on it,
n: or because of this curse he incites another to do it,
: and the person who erases this inscription and has written for him a name which should not be written,
n: whether that person be a king, or an en, or a governor, ...,

r.en: Enlil, ... towards the east, 
r.en: great north-wind of the Anunna gods ..., 
r.en: (for) Šulgi, the serpent bearing fearsomeness ..., 
r.en: for the king, whom he had wrought, he ... the eye. 
r.en: Very great strength he ... 
r.en: His noise ... heaven and earth, 
r.en: (in) the Ekur temple, a fierce snake which ... divine power, 
r.en: (in) Duranki a joy (where) the ancient divine attributes ..., 
r.en: within the brickwork founded by the prince, whose young shoot's days are prolonged, 
.en: for Šulgi, born for a prosperous reign, from the womb on he was destined for greatness. 
.en: Unifier of the people, 
.en: (you) who unto distant (time) is king of multitudes! 
.en: A runner, a tempestuous storm, whose loins keep going, 
.en: a runner who leaves behind all the settlements, 
.en: a frightening force, fiercest of all racers, 
.en: chosen from all the people, their strength, who ... the head. 
.en: when (his) tall arms are spread wide, toward his back ... 
.en: Šulgi, whose speeding has been repeatedly set(? from the horizon(?), 
.en: Because of his great strength, in his arms ever-expanding(?) ..., 
.en: tirelessly traveling powerfully(?) upon the road. 
.en: Among the Black Headed People no king had dared so much; he reached a great decision. 
.en: On a day that broke joyously, with clouds set for rain, 
.en: from the Ki'ur terrace of Nippur he decided to run 
.en: to the shrine of Ur, the Etemenniguru. 
.en: For Nanna in the morning dining hall where stood his princely bowl he provided the fitting regular offerings. 
.en: On this day he determined abundance as its fate. 
.en: A storm wind from the south(?), a whirlwind, broke out. 
.en: The sun dipped low in parallel, 
.en: but he arrived(?) back at the lapis lazuli Ekur. 
.en: That heroes for (future) lifetimes 
.en: would reveal in praise the very great magnificence of Šulgi, 
.en: his statue of distant days and eternal fame, 
.en: like the heavenly stars he colored it, 
.en: and by exalted father Enlil, him with unalterable verdicts, 
.en: with his good eyes, filled with delight, (clothed) with a princely garment, he set it up.

.en: On the day of the festival 
.en: in the temple of Ninmar, 
.en: when the first (offerings?) are taken into the courtyard: 
.en: 5 jugs of sweet-wort, 
.en: 7 jugs of beer, 
.en: 1 barig and 1 ban2 of royal flour, 
.en: 1 linen cover 
.en: and 1 linen (cloth) for the throne, 
.en: cedar sprouts(?) and cedar 'herders', 
.en: 7 times 2 minas of them, 
.en: 590 split fish,

r.en: Envoys of Aga, the son of Enmebaragesi, 
r.en: from Kish to Gilgamesh in Uruk came. 
r.en: Gilgamesh before the elders of his city, 
r.en: presented the issue, carefully choosing his words: 
r.en: There are wells to be finished, wells of the Land yet to be finished; 
r.en: there are shallow wells of the Land yet to be finished, 
r.en: there are wells to deepen and hoisting gear to be completed. 
r.en: To the house of Kish We should not submit! Should we not smite it with weapons? 
r.en: In the convened assembly, the elders of his city 
.en: answer Gilgamesh: 
.en: “There are indeed wells to be finished, wells of the Land yet to be finished; 
.en: there are shallow wells of the Land yet to be finished, 
.en: there are wells to deepen and hoisting gear to be completed. 
.en: So we should submit to the house of Kish. We should not smite it with weapons! 
.en: Gilgamesh, the lord of Kulaba, 
.en: in Inanna placing his trust 
.en: the advice of the elders of his city did not take seriously. 
.en: a second time Gilgamesh before the able-bodied men of his city 
.en: presented the issue, carefully choosing his words: 
.en: “There are wells to be finished, wells of the Land yet to be finished; 
.en: there are shallow wells of the Land yet to be finished, 
.en: there are wells to deepen and hoisting gear to be completed. 
.en: Never before have you submitted to the house of Kish. Should you not smite it with weapons? 
.en: In the convened assembly, the able-bodied men of his city answer Gilgamesh: 
.en: “Standing on duty and sitting in attendance, 
.en: the son of the king escorting, 
.en: the reins of the donkey always grasping, 
.en: who has the breath?,” as the saying goes. 
.en: To the house of Kish you all should not submit! With weapons should we not smite it?” 
.en: “The structure of Uruk, the handiwork of the gods, 
.en: and of Eanna, the house from heaven lowered down, 
.en: the great gods created. 
.en: The great wall, the wall which An founded, 
.en: the majestic residence which An established, 
.en: you watch over. You are its king and warrior, 
.en: an exuberant person, a prince by An beloved. 
.en: When Aga comes, what terror he will experience! 
.en: That army is small, at the rear scattered. 
.en: Its men will be incapable of confronting us.” 
.en: Then Gilgamesh, the lord of Kulaba, 
.en: at the advice of the able-bodied men of his city rejoiced and his spirit brightened. 
.en: His servant Enkidu he addressed: 
.en: “On this account let the weaponry and arms of battle be made ready. 
.en: Let the battle mace to your side return. 
.en: A great terror and radiance may they create. 
.en: When he comes, my great fearsomeness will overwhelm him. 
.en: His reasoning will become confused, his judgment disarrayed.” 
.en: Not 5 days, not 10 days had passed 
.en: when Aga, the son of Enmebaragesi, to Uruk with his men laid siege . 
.en: Uruk’s reasoning became confused. 
.en: Gilgamesh, the lord of Kulaba, 
.en: to its warriors speaks: 
.en: “My warriors shall have the choice. 
.en: Let someone with courage rise up, “I shall go against Aga” 
.en: Birḫurtura, his royal guard, 
.en: in admiration to his king says: 
.en: I shall go against Aga. 
.en: so that his reasoning will become confused, his judgment disarrayed.” 
.en: Birḫurtura through the city gate went out. 
.en: As soon as Birḫurtura went out through the city gate, 
.en: at the gate of the city gate they captured him, 
.en: Birḫurtura’s entire length beating. 
.en: Into the presence of Aga he came 
.en: speaking to Aga. 
.en: His words were not done, a “mirror-holder” of Uruk, on the wall climbing up, 
.en: out over the wall leaned. 
.en: Aga trained his eyes, 
.en: to Birḫurtura speaking: 
.en: “Slave, is that man your king?” 
.en: “That man is not my king! 
.en: Were that man my king, 
.en: were that his angry brow, 
.en: were those his bison eyes, 
.en: were that his lapis lazuli beard, 
.en: were those his elegant fingers, 
.en: would he not cast down multitudes? Would he not raise up multitudes? 
.en: Would multitudes not be smeared with dust? 
.en: Would not all the nations be overwhelmed? 
.en: Would not the (canal-)mouths of the land be filled with silt? 
.en: Would not the horns of the barges be broken? 
.en: Would he not take captive Aga, the king of Kish, in the midst of his army?” 
.en: Hitting him, striking him, 
.en: Birḫurtura’s entire length they were beating. 
.en: After the “mirror-holder” of Uruk, Gilgamesh climbs up on the wall. 
.en: the young and old of Kulaba his radiance overwhelms. 
.en: The able-bodied men of Uruk with battle maces he armed, 
.en: on the causeway at the door of the city gate stationed. 
.en: Enkidu through the city gate alone went out. 
.en: Gilgamesh out over the wall leaned. 
.en: Looking up, Aga opened his eyes: 
.en: “Slave, is that man your king?” 
.en: “That man is indeed my king.” 
.en: It was just as he had said: 
.en: Multitudes fell, multitudes rose up, 
.en: multitudes with dust were smeared, 
.en: all the nations were overwhelmed, 
.en: the (canal-)mouths of the land with silt were filled, 
.en: the horns of the barges were broken, 
.en: Aga, the king of Kish, in the midst of his army he took captive 
en: Gilgamesh, the lord of Kulaba, 
en: to Aga speaks: 
en: “Aga my foreman, Aga my lieutenant, 
en: Aga my commander of the troops! 
en: Aga gave me breath, Aga gave me life: 
en: Aga a fugitive into his embrace took, 
en: Aga the fleeing bird with grain provided.” 
en: “Uruk, the handiwork of the gods, 
en: the great wall, the wall which An founded, 
en: the majestic residence which An established, 
en: you watch over. You are its king and warrior, 
en: an exuberant person, a prince beloved of An.” 
en: “Before Utu, your former kindness is hereby repaid to you.” 
en: Aga to Kish he set free. 
en: As to Gilgamesh, lord of Kulaba, 
en: your praise is sweet. 
r.en: Enlil! Gutium,
r.en: the fanged snake of the mountain ranges,
r.en: a people who acted violently against the gods,
r.en: people who the kingship
r.en: of Sumer
r.en: to the mountains took away,
r.en: who Sumer
r.en: with wickedness filled,
r.en: who from one with a wife his wife
.en: took away from him,
.en: who from one with a child his child
.en: took away from him,
.en: who wickedness and violence
.en: produced within the country—
.en: Enlil, the king of all the lands,
.en: to obliterate its name,
.en: Utuḫegal,
.en: the mighty man,
.en: the king of Uruk,
.en: the king of the four world quarters,
.en: the king whose utterances cannot be countermanded,
.en: Enlil, the king of all the lands,
.en: issued to him a command about this.
.en: To Inanna his lady
.en: he went
.en: and prayed to her, (saying)
.en: “My lady, lioness of battle,
.en: who the foreign lands batters,
.en: Enlil, the kingship of Sumer
.en: to return to its own control
.en: he commanded me.
.en: May you be my ally.”
.en: An army of many foreigners
.en: bore down upon the land everywhere.
.en: Tirigan,
.en: the king of Gutium,
.en: opened its (canal?) mouths,
.en: but no one came out against him.
.en: Both banks of the Tigris
.en: he had seized.
.en: To the south, in Sumer,
.en: the cultivated land he tied up,
.en: to the north, the roads he tied up.
.en: On the highways of the country
.en: he made tall grasses grow.
.en: But the king to whom Enlil
.en: had given power,
.en: whom Inanna by (her own) heart had chosen,
.en: Utuḫegal, the mighty man,
.en: from Uruk went out against him.
.en: In the temple of Iškur
.en: he made an offering.
.en: To the citizens of his city
.en: he was calling out, (saying)
.en: “Gutium
.en: Enlil has given to me.
.en: My mistress Inanna
.en: is my ally.
.en: Dumuzi-Ama’ušumgalana
.en: has declared ‛It is something that concerns me,’
.en: and Gilgameš,
.en: the son of Ninsun,
.en: as bailiff he has given to me.”
.en: The citizens of Uruk
.en: and the citizens of Kullab
.en: he caused to rejoice at this.
.en: His city, as one man,
.en: followed after him.
.en: The military contingents and scouts
.en: he put in good order.
.en: After having departed from the temple of Iškur,
.en: on the 4th day in Nagsu on the Enurigal canal
.en: he made an offering.
.en: On the 5th day at Bara-Ilitappe
.en: he made an offering.
.en: Ur-Ninazu
.en: and Nabi-Enlil,
.en: generals of Tirigan
.en: who to Sumer as envoys
.en: had been sent,
.en: he captured and put fetters on their hands.
.en: Having departed from Bara-Ilitappe,
.en: on the 6th day at Karkar
.en: he made an offering.
.en: He went in to Iškur
.en: and prayed to him.
.en: “O Iškur, Enlil has given me the weapons,
.en: may you be my ally.”
.en: In the middle of that night he arose,
.en: and north of Adab,
.en: when Utu had risen,
.en: he went
.en: and prayed to him, (saying)
.en: “O Utu, Gutium
.en: Enlil has given to me,
.en: may you be my ally.”
.en: At that place, (just) beyond Gutium,
.en: he laid a trap(?) for him,
.en: and the troops he drove to him.
en: Utuḫegal, the mighty man,
en: defeated
en: their generals. Whereupon, Tirigan,
en: king of Gutium,
en: fled all alone from there.
en: The place where to save his life
en: he had fled,
en: in Dabrum, they (at first) were good to him.
en: (But) the people of Dabrum,
en: Utuḫegal,
en: because, he a king to whom Enlil had given power
en: he was, they had realized,
en: Tirigan
en: they did not let go.
en: By the envoys of Utuḫegal
en: Tirigan
en: and his wife and children
en: in Dabrum were captured.
en: They placed fetters on his hands
en: and put a cloth (blindfold) over his eyes.
en: Utuḫegal before Utu
en: made him lie at his (Utu’s) feet,
en: and on his neck he set his foot.
en: Gutium, the fanged snake of the mountain ranges,
en: he made drink from the cracks in the earth.
en: he made an offering.
en: The tow-boats he dispatched from its borders,
en: and the kingship of Sumer to its control he returned.

.en: A person who a wicked command
.en: shall issue against it, and that which I have fashioned
.en: shall efface,
.en: or shall erase its inscription  
.en: and write his own name upon it,
.en: or, because of the curse, another person
.en: he shall get to raise a hand against it,

.en: an en-priest, or an ordinary living person
.en: called by name,

.en: and its restoring,

.en: the Tigris, 
.en: Utu’s river of abundance, 
.en: by means of my triumph 
.en: I dug there in a grand fashion. 
.en: Up to the border territory, my chosen boundary mound, 
.en: I brought its beginning, 
.en: and into a marsh 
.en: I directed it in a great fashion. 
.en: (Thus) a constant water supply, 
.en: a ceaseless abundance, 
.en: to my city Larsa of the nation  
.en: I established.
.en: When the Tigris, the great river, 
.en: I dug, 
.en: the wages for one man were 
.en: 1 kor barley each, 
.en: 2 sila bread each, 
.en: 4 sila beer each 
.en: and 2 shekels oil each, 
.en: in one day 
.en: thusly they received it.
.en: Either a man less wages, 
.en: or a man more wages 
.en: I did not let him take.
.en: Through the strength of the land 
.en: I completed that work. 
.en: By means of the commands and divine decisions 
.en: of the great gods 
.en: the Tigris, the wide river, 
.en: I returned to its former place,
.en: and (so) for all future time 
.en: I have indeed made my name stand forth.
