.en: Nanna my master 
.en: was agreeable to me. 
.en: The great city wall, raised up like a mountain range 
.en: which cannot be opposed, 
.en: which came forth on its own,  
.en: I built for him. 
.en: Of that wall 
.en: Nanna Keeps Secure the Foundation of the Nation 
.en: is its name. 
.en: For all the things I was able to do, 
.en: O Nanna my master 
.en: may you be happy with me. 
.en: May a fate of life, 
.en: a long reign, 
.en: and a throne with a firm foundation 
.en: as a gift 
.en: be presented to me. 
r.en: I, Warad-Sîn, 
r.en: the mighty man, 
r.en: shepherd who makes justice blossom, 
r.en: beloved of Enlil, 
r.en: Nanna and Utu, 
r.en: who reveres the Ebabbar, 
r.en: provider of the Ekur, 
r.en: the man who pleases the heart of Nippur, 
r.en: the constant supporter of the Ekišnugal, 
.en: king of Larsa 
.en: and king of Sumer and Akkad, 
.en: son of Kudur-mabuk  
.en: and father of Emutbala -
.en: Nanna my master, with my making excellent words, 
.en: about widening Ur, 
.en: expanding its platform  
.en: more than any previous one, 
.en: enlarging its grounds, 
.en: and (so) making it acquire a great name,  
.en: after I made (oracular) inquiries, 
.en: I trod after him 
.en: and humbly addressed pleas for it.
.en:  Nanna my master was agreeable to me.
.en: For my life and the life 
.en: of Kudur-mabuk, the father who begot me, 
.en: in the city, the mountain of life 
.en: and place of abundance, 
.en: the residence (where) the assembly of the gods  
.en: determined his destiny, 
.en: which like his name is surpassing, 
.en: whose head reaches the sky, 
.en: whose arms seeking with hands the place where inquiries are placed, 
.en: whose wide shadow he therefore made to be over all the lands, 
.en: at its base he multiplied the Black Headed People,  
.en: they who betook their lives there,  
.en: its great wall I built.
.en: Like a verdant mountin range I made it grow upon a pure place. 
.en: Like its name and majesty I raised up its top there. 
.en: As a marvel of the nation I made it appear greatly resplendent. 
.en: When I built the wall of Ur, 
.en: the wages for one man were: 3 ban barley, 
.en: 2 sila bread, 2 sila beer, 
.en: and 2 shekels oil; 
.en: one received this per one day.
.en: Throughout my country I removed complaints.
.en: With my shining brow and happiness of heart 
.en: this work I joyfully and quickly finished.  
.en: With my wide intelligence and wisdom I built it grandly. 
.en: That wall Nanna Makes Firm the Foundation of the Country  
.en: I named. 
.en: For my deed, 
.en: O Nanna my master, may you rejoice over me,  
.en: and may days of happiness, a reign of abundance, 
.en: a good life, years of plenty,
.en: and a throne with a secure foundation  
.en: be presented to me. 
r.en: To Dingir-Mardu, 
r.en: his god, 
r.en: for the life 
r.en: of Warad-Sîn 
r.en: the king of Larsa, 
r.en: Alla-rapi, 
r.en: son(?) of Uku'a, 
r.en: as(?) his servant,
r.en: dedicated it (this object). 
r.en: When An and Enlil 
r.en: the eternal princes, the fathers of the gods, 
r.en: they who decide the fates, 
r.en: to Nanna, the good son, 
r.en: the beloved of the Ekur - 
r.en: who daily, in humility, 
r.en: while prostrating himself  
r.en: standing before them, 
r.en: heeds what they say
.en: and bows to their commands - 
.en: they spoke to him happily. 
.en: The counsel of heaven and earth,  
.en: the good advice and divine decisions of the Anunna gods, 
.en: they placed in his hands. 
.en: In his city Ur, the demarcated territory of the gods,  
.en: to exercise a good reign for the future, 
.en: to raise high its dais(es), 
.en: and all the assembly of living beings 
.en: to make bear tribute
.en: and set it down at his feet and his hands, 
.en: their holy word, which cannot be altered, 
.en: they firmly spoke. 
.en: At that time, Ašimbabbar, 
.en: wise as to decisions, the son of Ninlil, 
.en: who before An and Enlil 
.en: in beauty had come forth head held high, 
.en: who soothes the land with his word, 
.en: who has faithfully manifested it to the Black Headed People,  
.en: and has shown compassion to its numerous people, 
.en: in his city Ur, the weak(?) mother of the land, 
.en: with his shining brow and happy heart
.en: he(?) looked at her(?),
.en: and having raised his head  
.en: he made it acquire an exalted name. 
.en: Letting it have the use of the abundance of the sea and mountains 
.en: and (as well) making it rush into war and battle in the nation,   
.en: he gave it as a gift.
.en: To provide refuge for the living, 
.en: to return what was their land to their control, 
.en: to establish water therein, and (so) to prolong their lives 
.en: by their word they brought him to do this. 
.en: For this, Warad-Sîn, 
.en: me, the wise one possessing intelligence, who loves what is right, 
.en: me who was colored(?) in sacred fashion from the very womb of my mother, 
.en: he (Nanna) placed me in the position of shepherd in his land. 
.en: For my rectitude he gave me the scepter, 
.en: bestowed upon me a happy reign, 
.en: and made his numerous people dwell under my command.  
.en: To renovate the Etemenniguru temple, 
.en: to thicken the base(?) of the shrine Ebabbar, 
.en: to rebuild the cities of the gods of the land, 
.en: to ... their fallen ...
.en: to raise high the old divine plans, 
.en: to restore their forgotten lustration rites,
.en: Nanna, the lord who perfects the divine attributes of heaen and earth, 
.en: because of my reverence he ordered me to do this. 
.en: My counsel for that(?) is a superior thing,  
.en: my skillful care is a thing that cannot be disrupted. 
.en: About lettiing my people know the ways of my kingship 
.en: about making my greatness and majesty exist forever, 
.en: about widening Ur,   
.en: expanding its platform,
.en: and greater than previously  
.en: enlarging its grounds,  
.en: after I had inquired about these (things), I trod after him 
.en: and humbly I addressed pleas to him.
.en: Nanna, my master, was agreeable to me. 
.en: For my life and the life 
.en: of Kudur-mabuk, the father who begot me - 
.en: the city, the mountain of life and place of abundance, 
.en: the residence and assembly (place) of the gods, 
.en: whose destiny they (the gods) having decided, 
.en: whose name is surpassing, 
.en: with top reaching the heavens, 
.en: whose arms seek with the hands the put inquiries, 
.en: whose wide shadow covers foreign land as well as the nation, 
.en: from whose good base the Black Headed People 
.en: he has multiplied, those who betake their lives (there) -
.en: the building of its wall he placed in my hands.  
.en: In the middle of that, five months had not elapsed 
.en: when I had baked its bricks.
.en: I finished that great wall 
.en: and raised up its parapets. 
.en: Like a verdant mountain range I made it grow on a pure place. 
.en: Its height I made surpassing and set free its awesome radiance. 
.en: Commensurate with its name and greatness I raised up its top. 
.en: As a marvel of the nation 
.en: I made it grandly resplendent.  
.en: In its foundations, for the foundation documents of my kingship 
.en: I sought out the place. 
.en: I raised the top of its main gate. 
.en: I strengthened its demarcating levee, 
.en: circled it with bricks, 
.en: and dug its moat. 
.en: I heaped up its ... 
.en: When the wall of Ur 
.en: I built, 
.en: the wages for one man were: 3 ban barley, 
.en: 2 sila bread, 2 sila beer, 2 shekels oil, 
en: in one day a man received thus. 
en: From the midst of my land 
en: I removed (cause for) complaint. 
en: With my shining brow and happy heart 
en: I finished this work quickly and joyfully. 
en: With my wide intelligence and wisdom I did the work in grand fashion. 
en: That wall: Nanna Makes Firm the Foundations of the Land 
en: I named it.
en: For my deeds, O Nanna my master, may you rejoice over me,  
en: and may days of happiness, a reign of abundance, 
en: a fate which cannot be overturned(?), years of plenty, 
en: a good life as (my) lot and kingship as (my) portion, 
en: be presented to me.
en: May my shepherdship in Nippur, Ur, and Larsa
en: never ever be altered. 
en: May I be the prince beloved of Nanna and Ningal. 
en: May my days be long. 
r.en: For Nininsina, 
r.en: the great lady, the mother of the nation, 
r.en: who creates the living things of the nation, 
r.en: first-born child of holy An, 
r.en: his mistress - 
r.en: Warad-Sîn, 
r.en: the mighty man, 
r.en: provider of Ur, 
r.en: king of Larsa 
.en: and king of Sumer and Akkad, 
.en: shepherd who perfects justice and the divine plans, 
.en: the Plant of Life temple, 
.en: the sacred dining hall, 
.en: her place of relaxation -
.en: her temple which in a past time 
.en: had been built and had grown old - 
.en: for his life
.en: and the life 
.en: of Kudur-mabuk 
.en: the father who begot him, 
.en: he rebuilt for her 
.en: and restored for her. 
.en: In her residence that gladdens the heart 
.en: I caused her to dwell in grand fashion, 
.en: and my royal name 
.en: I put there everlastingly. 
.en: For ever after today 
.en: to cause the praising of me, 
.en: foundation document(s) in praise of my princeliness 
.en: into its foundation I buried, 
.en: and a pure brick wall for it I placed upon it. 
.en: For my deeds, 
.en: O Nininsina 
.en: my mistress, may you rejoice over me. 
.en: May a fate of life, 
.en: a long reign, years of abundance, 
.en: and a throne with a secure foundation 
.en: be presented to me.
.en: In the shrine of Larsa, 
.en: the city where I was created,  
.en: may my days be long.
r.en: For Nergal, 
r.en: mighty lord of the netherworld, strong one, 
r.en: first-born son of Enlil, 
r.en: my master, 
r.en: I, Warad-Sîn, 
r.en: who takes care of the Ebabbar temple,

.en: did repay, 
.en: who most humbly before the great gods 
.en: stands serving for his life's sake, 
.en: (for) Nergal, 
.en: through his ...
.en: the helper of my weapon, 
.en: in my having established a colleague status (with him), 
.en: his old temple  
.en: the sacred temple and residence which gladdens his heart, 
.en: for my life 
.en: and the life

r.en: lord, great hero,

.en: son of Kudur-mabuk 
.en: and father of Emutbala, 
.en: shepherd of justice 
.en: who made the wide peoples 
.en: lie down in fine meadows - 
.en: because in my place of Raised Hand prayers 
.en: you stood by me, 
.en: and my enemies 
.en: you put fully into my hands, 
.en: therefore 
.en: for Zababa, 
.en: the lord of my favorable signs, 
.en: whereas I had established a colleague status (with him), 
.en: his temple 
.en: in Ur 
.en: for my life 
.en: I did indeed build for him.

.en: Temple - Residence that Cools the Heart
.en: I named it.

r.en: when Nanna

.en: you stood by me: 
.en: that the Nanna Rejoices canal 
.en: I shall dig

.en: son of Kudur-mabuk 
.en: and father of Emutbala, 
.en: when Ningublaga my master 
.en: had brought his instructions:  
.en: that I shall make the people who are hostile to me submit to me 
.en: and settle the kings who hated me under my command, 
.en: because of this, 
.en: while I was making beautiful words (of prayer),  
.en: the Egabura temple,  
.en: with cattle pens for butterfat and cheese, a mountain of abundance, 
.en: his sacred dining hall with things required for a deity,  
.en: and with all kinds of water, I built 
.en: and restored. 
.en: The greatness of my kingship 
.en: I let be seen throughout the nation, 
.en: and my great name
.en: I established there forever.

.en: he had laid his foot,

.en: he built for her.

.en: Ninlil, his mistress, 
.en: at his making words beautiful, 
.en: listened to his prayers
.en: and was agreeable to his Raised Hand entreaties. 
.en: At that time, the Temple Worthy of its Lady, 
.en: her belovd residence, 
.en: for his life 
.en: he built for her.

.en: raised up its top, 
.en: and made it grow for her like a mountain range.

.en: I struck with weapons, 
.en: and in that battle I captured ARADnene, the king of Uruk, 
.en: through the word of An the king of the gods, 
.en: through the exalted utterance of Enlil my master, 
.en: through Ninlil my mistress, 
.en: through Ninurta the mighty hero, my one who goes at the right side, 
.en: through Nuska the chief minister and father of my palace,

.en: through the power of Nergal, the god who begot me, 
.en: through Inanna, the mistress of my battles, 
.en: through Nininsina, the mistress of my military forces, 
.en: through Ninšenšena my one who shines for me -  
.en: when the various cities of the land of Uruk I had struck down, 
.en: and the booty and property, however much it was, 
.en: to Larsa 
.en: I had brought in, 
.en: at that time, to Ningišzida 
.en: my master 
.en: while I was making beautiful words (of prayer) 
.en: the Temple of Righteousness, 
.en: his beloved residence, 
.en: I built for him for my life. 
.en: I raised up its top 
.en: and made it grow up like a mountain range.

r.en: When An, Enlil, Enki, and Ninmah
r.en: directed a righteous eye towards me, 
r.en: and when for Larsa, their beloved leveled place, 
r.en: they determined its destiny.  
r.en: and with their unalterable word they commanded its creation, 
r.en: and a reign of abundance with unceasing water 
r.en: they presented to me. 
r.en: Everlasting water as the portion of the nation, 
r.en: water which the Tigris and Euphrates 
.en: since ancient times had always brought forth
.en: and at no time ever ceases, 
.en: half of it the Mamišarrat Canal, the canal of abundance of the nation,  
.en: whose waters were from the Tigris and the Euphrates, 
.en: when it had taken them away from there 
.en: it poured them into the Sea. 
.en: Lord Nunamnir, whose utterances create with great care, 
.en: turned towards the shepherd who pleased him 
.en: and, having spoken joyously, determined for him a good fate: 
.en: (namely) to dig canals in order into Sumer and Akkad    
.en: to bring waters of abundance, 
.en: to make the speckled barley grow on its great agricultural tracts, 
.en: to make its irrigated orchards richly produce date syrup and grapes, 
.en: to make its marshes joyfully provide fish and birds,  
.en: Great Mountain Enlil issued the great orders.   
.en: I who am the (god-)fearing shepherd who walks beside Enlil,  
.en: I, Rīm-Sîn, who am the man of Great Mountain Enlil,  
.en: one who possesses wisdom and perfects true intelligence, 
.en: I, Rīm-Sîn, the faithful shepherd of the Blacked Headed (People),  
.en: when the wide wisdom given to me by Enki  
.en: he improved(?) regarding it, to dig the canal 
.en: he inspired me. 
.en: When Enlil(?) had inspired(?) me to do it, 
.en: that canal alongside the Mama-šarrat canal, the canal of abundance of the nation, 
.en: ... I dug, 
.en: and skillfully I executed the plans ... 
.en: When the numerous peoples whose shepherding Enlil gave to me 
.en: from below and above I had brought together, 
.en: by my mighty strength I did the task.
.en: When I had built its two levees like a mountain range, I filled them up with divine radiance. 
.en: After I had secured abundant water at its intake,  
.en: I continued extending its outlet. 
.en: Upon its banks I multiplied luxuriant sweet-smelling grasses. 
.en: That canal - the Tuqmat-Erra Canal 
.en: they named it. 
.en: The everlasting waters of both the Tigris and the Euphrates  
.en: I restored.
.en: I, Rīm-Sîn, the king of Larsa 
.en: and king of Sumer and Akkad, 
.en: I made secure the foundations of my wide country. 
.en: I restored its cities and settlements. 
.en: For my numerous people I established food to eat and water to drink. 
.en: When I had unified harmoniously Sumer and Akkad, 
.en: I indeed pleased the heart of Enlil. 
.en: For this, may An, Enlil, Enki and Ninmah 
.en: give to me a long life,  
.en: and a reign of abundance, a throne with a firm foundation 
.en: may they present to me. 
.en: When I have had foundation documents inscribed to praise my royal revealed name, 
.en: the numerous peoples will praise me forever.

r.en: Enanedu, 
r.en: en priestess of Nanna, 
r.en: having the great fate of the en office from the womb on, a nobility of heaven, 
r.en: beloved of (her) heart, the brightness(?) of the en office set upon her body by Ningal's own hand,  
r.en: fitting one of the Ekišnugal temple, the rival of high heaven, 
r.en: ornament of the agrun cella, burning light coming forth for the nation, 
r.en: sacredly suited for the crown of the en office, 
r.en: properly chosen for the divine plans and lustrations of the en office, 
r.en: reverent princess who serves at the lustrations for the exalted platform of the royal house, 
.en: I, Enanedu, 
.en: the en priestess who may look upon Nanna and Ningal 
.en: (in) Ur, the foremost city of Sumer, 
.en: where zanaru instruments are played for Ašimbabbar, 
.en: a person most fitting for the gipar built on a pure place for its office of en - 
.en: when Nanna and Ningal 
.en: having looked (at me) with their shining brows, and life 
.en: and a joyous regard they gave to me,  
.en: and in the shrine Ekišnugal, the residence of their divinity, 
.en: they having exalted my name,  
.en: having placed in my pure mouth prayers of life,
.en: and my correctly guiding hand - in order that the life of Rīm-Sîn, 
.en: my twin(!) brother, 
.en: could be extended - they, togther with him, did exert it,  
.en: and so his foreign enemies 
.en: they having put fully into his hands -
.en: at that time, the sacred gipar, my residence of the en office, 
.en: its bricks no longer lying against(?) its base, 
.en: I, Enanedu, 
.en: en priestess, truly named with an exalted name, 
.en: the daughter of Kudur-mabuk, 
.en: I laid correctly fitting bricks against the old base of the sacred gipar. 
.en: I covered with plaster its inner walls fitted to (within) a finger-length. 
.en: I created that house anew. 
.en: At that time, the Hall That Has Brought Bitterness, the cleared land of 'fates' 
.en: (where) the old en priestesses were, 
.en: that place was not encircled with a wall, and its entrances and its .. had collapsed. 
.en: No watch was set up and that place was no longer pure. 
.en: I, by my great wisdom, 
.en: sought out a place for (going to one's) fate forever afterward.  
.en: Surpassing the resting place of the old en priestesses 
.en: I established a broad sacred area. 
.en: I surrounded that collapsed place with a big wall,
.en: set there a strong watch, and I purified that place. 
.en: To show my name chosen for the office of en,  
.en: I did indeed restore this work. 
.en: Foundation documents in praise of my office of en I had inscribed 
.en: and had it laid there for whatsoever time it may exist.  
.en: I named that wall: May the One Who Shows Fear of Me Be Praised.

r.en: son of Sîn-ublam, 
r.en: servant of Rīm-Sîn. 
r.en: ...-bani,

r.en: Ibbi-Enlil, 
r.en: son of Išdu-kīn, 
r.en: servant of Enanedu. 
r.en: For Inanna, 
r.en: the angry goddess, with head held high in the throne room, 
r.en: exalted one, brightest in all the lands, 
r.en: whose face is full of radiance, 
r.en: steadfast goddess whose proud heart is good,  
r.en: she of far-reaching compassion who those in straights and sickness  
r.en: she knows well how to take in hand, 
r.en: my lady - 
r.en: for the life 
.en: of Rīm-Sîn, 
.en: king of Larsa, 
.en: and of Lirīš-gamlum his daughter, 
.en: I, Rīm-Sîn-Šala-bāštašu, 
.en: beloved wife of Rīm-Sîn,
.en: daughter of Sîn-māgir,
.en: the humble woman, 
.en: ornament worthy of kingship -  
.en: when my lady by a beautiful name 
.en: truly called me, 
.en: for this, to Inanna, 
.en: as I made fine words (of prayer), 
.en: a vessel of diorite stone
.en: suitable for pure touching-water - 
.en: something which previously no queen who came before me 
.en: had ever fashioned - 
.en: when I had fashioned it, 
.en: at the sacred gate of the main courtyard of the Emeurur temple 
.en: a place of marvel of the nation 
.en: I happily set it up . 
.en: In order from evil-doers and violent men  
.en: to keep Lirīš-gamlum away,  
.en: and the asakku or ašbur diseases that may be in her body 
.en: to give over (instead) to that which knows not fear, 
.en: to remove the šahal from within her eye, 
.en: and to act as guardian for her life, 
.en: for the life of Lirīš-gamlum my daughter 
.en: and for my own life, 
.en: I, the servant who has fear of her (Inanna),
.en: dedicated it (this object) to her.
.en: For ever after today,  
.en: a person who may efface the work I have made, 
.en: who shall remove it from its standing place 
.en: and stand it up in another place, 
.en: who shall erase its inscription 
.en: and inscribe his own name upon it, 
.en: or because of this curse 
.en: shall incite a stranger to it,  
.en: upon that person may Inanna, queen of all the lands, 
.en: with her angry heart and fury  
.en: wreak upon him a grievous curse.

.en: and (so) for my life 
.en: they indeed prayed.

.en: and Aia my mistress 
.en: was good I did. 
.en: That my good name 
.en: daily 
.en: might be revealed like (that of) a god, 
.en: and that forever 
.en: it may not be forgotten, 
.en: I put it in the mouths of the people.

.en: foundation, like that of heaven and earth
.en: did make firm for him -
.en: then Marduk,
.en: the Enlil of his land,
.en: the god who wisdom
.en: creates,
.en: to me, Samsu-iluna,
.en: who is the king his delight,
.en: of all those lands
.en: to exercise their shepherding
.en: he did give me,
.en: and his country
.en: to make lie down in riverine meadows,
.en: and his wide-spread people
.en: to lead forever in well-being,
.en: he issued to me (these) great instructions.
.en: I, Samsu-iluna,
.en: the mighty king,
.en: king of Babylon,
.en: king who among the four world quarters
.en: established harmony,
.en: by my own power
.en: and through my great intelligence,
.en: the fort Dimat-Enlil
.en: for Ningursaga
.en: the mother who created me,
.en: the fort Pada
.en: for Iškur my helper,
.en: the fort Lagaba
.en: for Nanna
.en: the god who goes at my head,
.en: the fort Iri-Iabušum
.en: for Šar-ṣarbatim
.en: because my kingship
.en: he had made very great,
.en: the fort Iri-Gulaba
.en: and the fort Uṣi-ana-Erra
.en: for Nergal
.en: because the smiting of my foes
.en: he did accomplish,
.en: these six great fortressess
.en: which Sūmû-la-Il,
.en: my forefather
.en: my fifth(-generation) ancestor,
.en: did build,
.en: but which in their old age by themselves
.en: did collapse,
.en: within two months
.en: their bricks I had made,
.en: and I rebuilt them in a grand fashion.
.en: Their tops I raised up like mountains,
.en: (and thus) of the whole of the lands
.en: their foundations I made secure.
.en: Babylon's
.en: name I made supreme,
.en: and within the four world quarters I truly made it pre-eminent.
.en: The fearsomeness of the divine radiance
.en: of my kingship
.en: truly covered the edges of heaven and earth.
.en: For this,
.en: the great gods
.en: their shining faces
.en: they directed towards me,
.en: and life, which like (the moon-god) Nanna
.en: waxes month after month,
.en: shepherdship of the four world quarters
.en: to exercise in well-being forever,
.en: the desire of my heart
.en: to attain like a god,
.en: (and) daily with an uplifted head
.en: to walk in joy and happiness
.en: they presented to me as a gift.

r.en: Enlil, whose kingship
r.en: of all the gods
r.en: is the greatest,
r.en: the shepherd who determines the destinies,
r.en: because Zababa and Inanna
r.en: among the great (divine) princes
r.en: were the most heroic,
r.en: he looked at them with his holy eyes.
r.en: The city Kiš,
.en: their foremost cult site
.en: and exalted residence,
.en: to build its wall
.en: and to raise up its top more than before
.en: his heart truly moved him.
.en: And Enlil, the great lord,
.en: whose utterance cannot be overturned
.en: and a fate which he determines
.en: cannot be altered,
en: To him (Zababa) who his victories
en: achieves,
en: and Inanna, the daughter
en: whom he loves,
en: the lady whose divinity
en: is unrivaled,
en: his joyful eyes he directed towards them, and
en: words of heart-felt happiness
en: he spoke with them.
en: Samsu-iluna,
en: my envoy, mighty
en: and untiring,
en: who the desire of my heart
en: knows how to put in place,
en: may you both be his shining light.
en: (Zababa and Ištar) the most majestic of the gods,
en: at the words that their father Enlil
en: had spoken to them,
en: their hearts rejoiced full of delight.
en: To Samsu-iluna,
en: the mighty king, the shepherd and hero,
en: their accomplishment,
en: their countenances of life
en: they lifted shiningly towards him,
en: and joyfully they conversed with him.
en: O Samsu-iluna,
en: eternal seed of kingship,
en: one fitting for kingship,
en: Enlil
en: has magnified your destiny.
en: To act with well-being as (your) guardian genies
en: he has commanded us.
en: When we shall have gone at your right side
en: the persons who hate you

r.en: king

r.en: Schoolboy, where have you been going so long? 
r.en: To the school I have been going. 
r.en: In school, what were you doing? 
r.en: My tablet I recited, my lunch I ate; 
r.en: my tablet I prepared, wrote, finished, 
r.en: my ‘standing’ lines they set out for me, 
r.en: during afternoon meal my hand-tablet they prepared for me, 
r.en: when school was released, home I used to go, 
r.en: home I entered, my father was sitting there; 
.en: to my father about my hand-tablet I spoke, 
.en: my tablet I recited to him, my father was happy. 
.en: In the presence of my father I stood, indeed, 
.en: being thirsty, “Water let me drink!” 
.en: being hungry, “Bread give me!” 
.en: “My feet wash, my bed set up, I would lie down!” saying. 
.en: “In the morning wake me up, 
.en: that the morning not pass, my teacher will hit me. 
.en: In the morning at my rising, 
.en: (on) my mother my eye I placed, and 
.en: “My lunch give me, to school I wish to go” I said to her; 
.en: my mother two breads ... gave me, from her presence eating I left, 
.en: “My lunch give me, to school I am going.” 
.en: In school the man on term: “Why did the morning pass?” asked me, with fear my gut was torn; 
.en: into the presence of my teacher I enter, a place I took, 
.en: my school-father my tablet to me recited, 
.en: “... they cut it of” saying, beats me; 
.en: lunch ...; lunch ...; 
.en: the teacher, the instructions of the school checking, 
.en: the beater in the house and the street looked: “Your breast garment you do not tie?” saying, beating me. 
.en: My school-father my tablet brought me. 
.en: The man of the courtyard “Write!” said, ...; 
.en: my tablet I received, ...; 
.en: my tablet I write ...; 
.en: its unchecked places to words of mine I do not understand. 
.en: The man of ...: “Why, in my absence, do you talk?” asking, beats me. 
.en: The man of the switch: “Why, in my absence, the ‘true-neck’ did you not raise?” asking, beats me. 
.en: The man of the floorplan: “Why, in my absence, do you ...?” asking, beats me. 
.en: The man of the gate: “Why, in my absence, do you go out?” asking, beats me. 
.en: The man of the whip: “Why, in my absence, do you ... receive?” asking, beats me. 
.en: The man of Sumerian: “Sumerian you call that?” asking, beats me. 
.en: My teacher: “Your hand is not at all pretty” saying, beats me. 
.en: Scribal art I neglected, scribal art I let fall. 
.en: My teacher his words has not .... with you 
.en: in scribal art his strength he ... me; 
.en: the ‘edge’ of your words of scribal art ..., 
.en: the ‘edge’ of brotherhood, school ...; 
.en: his gift give, that he many times over give, 
.en: that he from the account-recitation release me; 
.en: of all the words that are in the school, 
.en: all the schoolboys counting, may he count me. 
.en: In what the schoolboy(s) had said, his father responded; 
.en: the teacher from school was brought round; 
.en: after the house he entered, in the “zamula” he sat; 
.en: the schoolboy bowed down, before him standing, 
.en: of scribal art what he had learned 
.en: into his father’s hand he gave. 
.en: His father from the joy of his gut 
.en: to the school-fathers friendly words speaks: 
.en: “My little one, his hand opening, into silver-knowledge you let him enter, 
.en: of scribal art, all its tricks, you reveal for him; 
.en: the gut of the tablet, the calculation of accounts, to its solutions you fill his eyes. 
.en: Of writing the covered places he lights up for him; 
.en: like good beer, oil and fragrances for him pour, the table set out for him; 
.en: good oil on his back and his gut like water offering, 
.en: “With a garment I will clad, a gift I will give him, a ring on his hand I will put!” 
.en: Like good beer, oil and fragrances for him he pours, the table he puts out for him, 
.en: good oil on his back and his gut like water he offers, 
.en: with a garment he clad, a gift he gave him, a ring on his hand he put. 
.en: The teacher in joy of gut a blessing spoke to him: 
.en: “The little one my words not having neglected, did not do let fall; 
.en: of the art of writing its head, to the very edge of its side, completed, 
.en: nothing shall be an obstacle for you, who into my hands gave, 
.en: to a gift that, in additional effort placed, heft you added, 
.en: may Nisaba, the lady of the protective deities, be your protective deity! 
.en: A pretty stylus may she place for you! 
.en: and if they of your tablet sing, “Bad!,” 
.en: of your ‘brothers’ may you their leader be! 
.en: Of your friends may you their hero be! 
.en: Exalted-schoolboy may you be! 
.en: passing by the house of the king, gut ...; 
.en: little one, father knows best; I am the one following him. 
.en: The blessing brought to you, your fate having been decided, 
.en: your god and father, with their words true hand may they set for you. 
.en: To Nisaba, your lady, as if your own god, blessings, offerings, prayers you will set, 
.en: your teacher, as if your own father, will bless you; 
.en: suchlike, the art of teaching, at the forehead of ‘big brothers,’ 
.en: good hand your having placed, 
.en: when your ... may they set; 
.en: to the instructions of the school light went out, making a man of wisdom; 
.en: Nisaba, lady of the place of wisdom, his greatness proclaimed; 
.en: Nisaba, praise! 
r.en: The princely lord, the princely lord came forth from the house. 
r.en: Enlil, the princely lord, came forth from the house. 
r.en: The princely lord came forth royally from the house. 
r.en: Enlil lifted his glance over all the lands, 
r.en: and the lands raised themselves to Enlil. 
r.en: The four corners of heaven became green for Enlil like a garden. 
r.en: Keš was positioned there for him with head uplifted, 
r.en: and as Keš lifted its head among all the lands, 
r.en: Enlil spoke the praises of Keš. 
.en: Nisaba was its decision-maker (?); 
.en: with its words she wove it intricately like a net. 
.en: Written on tablets it was held in her hands: 
.en: House, platform of the Land, important fierce bull! 
.en: House Keš, platform of the Land, important fierce bull! 
.en: Growing as high as the hills, embracing the heavens, 
.en: growing as high as E-kur, lifting its head among the mountains! 
.en: Rooted in the abzu, verdant like the mountains! 
.en: Will anyone else bring forth something as great as Keš? 
.en: Will any other mother ever give birth to someone as great as its hero Ašgi? 
.en: Who has ever seen anyone as great as its lady Nintur? 
.en: The 1st house. 
.en: Good house, built in a good location, house Keš, 
.en: built in a good location, 
.en: floating in the heavens like a princely barge, 
.en: like a holy barge furnished with a SI gate, 
.en: like the boat of heaven, the platform of all the lands!

.en: that person,
.en: be he a king,
.en: be he an en,
.en: be he a governor,
.en: be he a temple administrator,
.en: or be he a gudu4-priest chosen by extispicy,
.en: that person
.en: may Enlil
.en: and Ninlil
.en: curse!
.en: May they not allow him to get an heir;
.en: may they not allow him to establish a name in the country.
.en: But a person who these words
.en: does not alter,
.en: before Enlil
.en: and Ninlil
.en: may he find favor.
.en: Inscription

.en: belonging to a stone statue.

.en: beloved of Enlil,
.en: king whom Enlil
.en: in his heart
.en: did choose,
.en: the mighty king,
.en: king of Ur and
.en: king of the four world quarters,
.en: for his life
.en: he dedicated it to him.

r.en: For Nanna,
r.en: the lord, the great lion of heaven and earth,
r.en: his master,
r.en: Ibbi-Sîn,
r.en: the god of his country,
r.en: the sovereign who, how every sort of divine attribute
r.en: should be properly performed, knows fully,
r.en: the mighty king,
r.en: king of Ur
.en: and king of the four world quarters,
.en: when in Susa,
.en: Adamšaḫ,
.en: (and) the land of Awan
.en: he roared like a storm,
.en: made them submit in a single day,
.en: and took their lord(s) into captivity,
.en: because Nanna
.en: had brought them back in his great arm,
.en: and had taken away their heavy gold and dark(?) silver,
.en: Ibbi-Sîn,
.en: the prince with great power, clad in fearsomeness,
.en: with wide intelligence -
.en: a golden seven-teat jar,
.en: whose openings let out honeyed water(?),
.en: whose golden (drinking) reed
.en: is a channel running majestically,
.en: a thing fit for the first-fruits offerings,
.en: whose copper sickles(?)
.en: are strong multiple reed ...,
.en: a mountain range growing pure clean junipers,
.en: with breasts making things numerous
.en: for(?) youthful Suen
.en: which are unceasing -
.en: for his life
.en: he dedicated it to him.
.en: A person who the order of an evil thing
.en: shall issue regarding it,
.en: and from the exalted platform of the (divine) dining hall
.en: and the festival place
.en: of Nanna
.en: shall cause it to be held back,
.en: may the great gods of heaven and earth
.en: curse him.
r.en: O Enlil with exalted utterances, your judgments being high and wide, 
r.en: issuing divine decisions, whose word cannot be altered, with ... planning placed in his hands, 
r.en: Išme-Dagan, the strong young man with the muscles and body of a lion, strong youth possessing fearsomeness, 
r.en: who alone is exalted, lord whose called good name is demonstrated in all lands, 
r.en: under his sway he has made the living creatures numerous, 
r.en: and into whose hand were given the Black Headed People in their shelters where the people reside, 
r.en: They prepared correctly for him the first-fruit offerings of the land. 
r.en: They are not (merely?) left to him in his good palace. 
r.en: At that time, Išme-Dagan, the youth, the hero of the runners, 
.en: to Nippur, being the city where the seed of the myriad people sprang up, where the living were born, 
.en: the reverent(?) runner who serves night and day without ceasing, 
.en: who daily brings everything (needed), made a great resolution. 
.en: When he rises up it is gigantic, a flood bringing a wind in its fury, 
.en: With his arms swinging open over and over, he flashes across distant miles 
.en: like a fierce lion of the steppe going with strength and youthfulness. 
.en: opening wide his knees on the highway, striding towards battle and combat, 
.en: like a horse ... on the highway with its tail extended, 
.en: like a buck when racing around inspiring fear ... 
.en: whose his knees when set free are untiring ..., 
.en: the son who brings everything for Enlil, 
.en: and also that which gladdens the heart of Ninlil, 
.en: the king cares unceasingly for the lapis lazuli shrine. 
.en: At that time, Išme-Dagan, a copper statue which inspires fear as it races against the storm, 
.en: in the temple clad in fearsomeness, upon his most precious dais, 
.en: he set it up and colored it brilliantly. 
.en: The great prince of the whole heaven, the lord whose utterance cannot be altered, 
.en: his shining brow and raised righteous eyes 
.en: may he let be upon him, directed towards the faithful shepherd whom he has engendered. 
.en: But a king who orders a wicked thing, 
.en: and erases this inscription and writes his own name upon it, 
.en: or because of this curse incites another person to do it, 
.en: may Enlil my master and Ninli my mistress curse that person. 
.en: May Enki, Iškur, Ezinu, and Šakan, the lords of abundance, 
.en: after locking up abundance in heaven and earth, ... him evilly. 
r.en: For Ninlil, the exalted queen,  
r.en: most resplendant of of the Anuna gods, 
r.en: ... in heaven and earth 
r.en: like ... 
.en: their daises ...
.en: their daises ...
.en: for kingship ...
en: he the one given the crown and scepter,
en: for the great mother of the Anuna gods, 
en: the mistress of the Ki'ur ...,
en: the exalted shrine Ekur's 
en: divine attributes to select, 
en: the Nippur shrine Duranki's 
en: ritual lustrations to cleanse, 
en: to make the divine rites that had fallen away 
en: reappear magnificently,
en: and Nippur, the bellwether of the nation,
en: to restore to its previous state,
en: it was Ur-Ninurta,
en: the one serving the Ekur,
en: upon whom Enlil, the king of all the lands,
en: out over the broad population
en: did lift his eye
en: and did rightly choose.
en: (for) An, Enlil, (and) Ninlil
en: I removed evil,
en: and (in) the shining Ekur temple in the city ... 
en: I set them up for them.
en: (Further,) copper figures whose bodily features  
en: were made to resemble me, 
en: with an offering kid,
en: were made in miniature(?), 
en: and, set up for (the delivering of) my prayers, 
en: as the main courtyard of the Gagiššua's  
en: ornament, I fashioned for her (Ninlil), 
en: and for my life
en: I dedicated them to her.
en: A person who an order of wickedness  
en: shall issue against it,
en: and my creation 
en: shall efface,
en: by the exalted command of Enlil
en: ... may his revealed name   
en: be revoked from within the Ekur.
en: May Ninurta, the mighty warrior of Enlil, 
en: be the inseparable bailiff for this
en: for an eternity of days!

.en: Ninlil, with a happy heart

.en: She abandoned the E-šara in Adab, and descended to the underworld.

.en: She took the seven divine powers. 
.en: She collected the divine powers and grasped them in her hand. 
.en: With the good divine powers, she went on her way. 
.en: She put a turban, headgear for the open country, on her head. 
.en: She took a wig for her forehead. 
.en: She hung small lapis-lazuli beads around her neck. 
.en: She placed twin egg-shaped beads on her breast. 
.en: She covered her body with a pala dress, the garment of ladyship. 
.en: She placed mascara “Let a man come, let him come” on her eyes. 
.en: She pulled the pectoral “Come, man, come” over her breast. 
.en: She placed a golden ring on her hand. 
.en: She held the lapis-lazuli measuring rod and measuring line in her hand. 
.en: Inanna traveled towards the underworld. 
.en: Her minister Ninšubur traveled behind her. 
.en: Holy Inanna says to Ninšubur: 
.en: “Come my faithful minister of Eanna, 
.en: my minister who speaks fair words, 
.en: my escort who speaks trustworthy words 
.en: “On this day I will descend to the underworld. 
.en: When I have arrived in the underworld, 
.en: make a lament for me on the ruin mounds. 
.en: Beat the drum for me in the sanctuary. 
.en: Make the rounds of the houses of the gods for me. 
.en: “Lacerate your eyes for me, lacerate your nose for me. 
.en: In private, lacerate your buttocks for me. 
.en: Like a pauper, clothe yourself in a single garment 
.en: and all alone set your foot in the E-kur, the house of Enlil.

.en: When Inanna arrived at the palace Ganzer,

.en: Neti, the chief doorman of the underworld,

.en: “If you are Inanna going to the east, 
.en: why have you traveled to the land of no return? 
.en: How did you set your heart on the road whose traveller never returns?”

.en: “Because lord Gud-gal-ana,

en: When she heard this, Ereškigal slapped the side of her thigh. 
en: She bit her lip and took the words to heart. 
en: She says to Neti, her chief doorman: 
en: “Come Neti, my chief doorman of the underworld, 
en: don’t neglect the instructions I will give you.

en: Then let each door of the palace Ganzer be opened separately. 
en: As for her, after she has entered, 
en: and crouched down and had her clothes removed, they will be carried away.” 
en: Neti, the chief doorman of the underworld, 
en: paid attention to the instructions of his mistress. 
en: He bolted the 7 gates of the underworld. 
en: Then he opened each of the doors of the palace Ganzer separately. 
en: He says to holy Inanna: 
en: “Come on, Inanna, and enter.” 
en: And when Inanna entered,

en: “What is this?” 
en: “Be satisfied, Inanna, a divine power of the underworld has been fulfilled. 
en: Inanna, you must not open your mouth against the rites of the underworld.”

en: “Be satisfied, Inanna, a divine power of the underworld has been fulfilled.

en: “Be satisfied, Inanna, a divine power of the underworld has been fulfilled.

en: When she entered the 5th gate, 
en: the golden ring was removed from her hand.

en: “Be satisfied, Inanna, a divine power of the underworld has been fulfilled.

en: “Be satisfied, Inanna, a divine power of the underworld has been fulfilled.

en: When she entered the 7th gate, 
en: the pala dress, the garment of ladyship, was removed from her body. 
en: “What is this?” 
en: “Be satisfied, Inanna, a divine power of the underworld has been fulfilled. 
en: Inanna, you must not open your mouth against the rites of the underworld.” 
en: After she had crouched down and had her clothes removed, they were carried away. 
en: Then she made her sister Ereškigal rise from her throne, 
en: and instead she sat on her throne. 
en: The Anuna, the seven judges, rendered their decision against her. 
en: They looked at her—it was the look of death! 
en: They spoke to her—it was the speech of anger! 
en: They shouted at her—it was the shout of heavy guilt! 
en: The afflicted woman was turned into a corpse! 
en: And the corpse was hung on a hook. 
en: After 3 days and 3 nights had passed, 
en: her minister Ninšubur 
en: carried out the instructions of her mistress. 
en: She made a lament for her in her ruined (houses). 
en: She beat the drum for her in the sanctuaries. 
en: She made the rounds of the houses of the gods for her. 
en: She lacerated her eyes for her, she lacerated her nose. 
en: In private she lacerated her buttocks for her. 
en: Like a pauper, she clothed herself in a single garment, 
en: and all alone she set her foot in the E-kur, the house of Enlil. 
en: When she had entered the E-kur, the house of Enlil, 
en: she laments before Enlil: 
en: “Father Enlil, don’t let anyone kill your daughter in the underworld. 
en: Don’t let your precious metal be alloyed there with the dirt of the underworld. 
en: Don’t let your precious lapis lazuli be split there with the mason’s stone. 
en: Don’t let your boxwood be chopped up there with the carpenter’s wood. 
en: Don’t let young lady Inanna be killed in the underworld.” 
en: In his rage father Enlil answers Ninšubur: 
en: “My daughter craved the great heaven and she craved the great below as well. 
en: Inanna craved the great heaven and she craved the great below as well. 
en: The divine powers of the underworld are divine powers which should not be craved, for whoever gets them must remain in the underworld. 
en: Who, having got to that place, could then expect to come up again?” 
en: Thus father Enlil did not help in this matter, so she went to Ur. 
en: In the E-mud-kura at Ur, 
en: when she had entered the E-kišnugal, the house of Nanna, 
en: she laments before Nanna: 
en: “Father Nanna, don’t let your daughter be killed in the underworld. 
en: Don’t let your precious metal be alloyed there with the dirt of the underworld. 
en: Don’t let your precious lapis lazuli be split there with the mason’s stone. 
en: Don’t let your boxwood be chopped up there with the carpenter’s wood. 
en: Don’t let young lady Inanna be killed in the underworld.” 
en: In his rage father Nanna answers Ninšubur: 
en: “My daughter craved the great heaven and she craved the great below as well. 
en: Inanna craved the great heaven and she craved the great below as well. 
en: The divine powers of the underworld are divine powers which should not be craved, for whoever gets them must remain in the underworld. 
en: Who, having got to that place, could then expect to come up again?” 
en: Thus father Nanna did not help her in this matter, so she went to Eridu. 
en: In Eridu, when she had entered the house of Enki, 
en: xshe laments before Enki:xx 
en: “Father Enki, don’t let anyone kill your daughter in the underworld. 
en: Don’t let your precious metal be alloyed there with the dirt of the underworld. 
en: Don’t let your precious lapis lazuli be split there with the mason’s stone. 
en: Don’t let your boxwood be chopped up there with the carpenter’s wood. 
en: Don’t let young lady Inanna be killed in the underworld.” 
en: Father Enki answered Ninšubur: 
en: “What has my daughter done? She has me worried. 
en: What has Inanna done? She has me worried. 
en: What has the mistress of all the lands done? She has me worried. 
en: What has the hierodule of An done? She has me worried.” 
en: He removed some dirt from the tip of his fingernail and created the kur-gar. 
en: He removed some dirt from the tip of his 2nd fingernail and created the gala-tur. 
en: To the kur-gar he gave the life-giving plant. 
en: To the gala-tura he gave the life-giving water. 
en: Then father Enki speaks out to the gala-tura and the kur-gar: 
en: Go and direct your steps to the underworld. 
en: Flit past the door like flies. 
en: Slip through the door pivots like phantoms. 
en: The birth-mother, on account of her children, 
en: Ereškigal, is lying there. 
en: Her holy shoulders are not covered by a linen cloth. 
en: Her breasts are not full like a cagan vessel. 
en: Her nails are like a pickaxe (?) upon her. 
en: The hair on her head is bunched up as if it were leeks. 
en: “When she says “Oh my heart,” 
en: you are to say “You are troubled, our mistress, oh your heart.” 
en: When she says “Oh my liver,” 
en: you are to say “You are troubled, our mistress, oh your liver.” 
en: (She will then ask:) “Who are you? 
en: Speaking to you from my heart to your heart, from my liver to your liver— 
en: if you are gods, let me talk with you; 
en: if you are mortals, may a destiny be decreed for you.” 
en: Make her swear this by heaven and earth. 
en: Go on out, 
en: They will offer you a riverful of water—don’t accept it. 
en: They will offer you a field with its grain—don’t accept it. 
en: But say to her: “Give us the corpse hanging on the hook.” 
en: (She will answer:) “That is the corpse of your queen.” 
en: Say to her: “Whether it is that of our king, whether it is that of our queen, give it to us.” 
en: She will give you the corpse hanging on the hook. 
en: 1 of you sprinkle on it the life-giving plant and 1 the life-giving water. 
en: Thus let Inanna rise up.” 
en: The gala-tura and the kur-gar paid attention to the instructions of Enki. 
en: They flitted through the door like flies. 
en: They slipped through the door pivots like phantoms. 
en: The birth-mother, because of her children, 
en: Ereškigal, was lying there. 
en: Her holy shoulders were not covered by a linen cloth. 
en: Her breasts were not full like a cagan vessel. 
en: Her nails were like a pickaxe (?) upon her. 
en: The hair on her head was bunched up as if it were leeks. 
en: When she said “Oh my heart,” 
en: they said to her “You are troubled, our mistress, oh your heart.” 
en: When she said “Oh my liver,” 
en: they said to her “You are troubled, our mistress, oh your liver.” 
en: (Then she asked:) “Who are you? 
en: I tell you from my heart to your heart, from my liver to your liver— 
en: if you are gods, I will talk with you; 
en: if you are mortals, may a destiny be decreed for you.” 
en: They made her swear this by heaven and earth. 
en: they went on out, 
en: they were offered a river with its water—they did not accept it. 
en: They were offered a field with its grain—they did not accept it. 
en: They said to her: “Give us the corpse hanging on the hook.” 
en: Holy Ereškigal answers the gala-tura and the kur-gar: 
en: “The corpse is that of your queen.” 
en: They said to her: “Whether it is that of our king or that of our queen, give it to us.” 
en: They were given the corpse hanging on the hook. 
en: 1 of them sprinkled on it the life-giving plant and 1 the life-giving water. 
en: And thus Inanna rose up. 
en: Ereškigal says to the gala-tura and the kur-gar: 
en: “Bring your queen ..., your ... has been seized.” 
en: Inanna, because of Enki’s instructions, was about to ascend from the underworld. 
en: But as Inanna was about to ascend from the underworld, 
en: the Anuna seized her: 
en: “Who has ever ascended from the underworld, has ascended unscathed from the underworld? 
en: If Inanna is to ascend from the underworld, 
en: let her provide a substitute for herself.” 
en: So when Inanna left the underworld, 
en: the one in front of her, though not a minister, held a sceptre in his hand; 
en: the one behind her, though not an escort, carried a mace at his hip, 
en: while the small demons, like a reed enclosure, 
en: and the big demons, like the reeds of a fence, restrained her on all sides. 
en: Those who accompanied her, 
en: those who accompanied Inanna, 
en: know no food, know no drink, 
en: eat no flour offering 
en: and drink no libation. 
en: They accept no pleasant gifts. 
en: They take away the child hanging on a wet-nurse’s breasts. 
en: They crush no bitter garlic. 
en: They eat no fish, they eat no leeks. 
en: They, it was, who accompanied Inanna. 
en: After Inanna had ascended from the underworld,

.en: he was brought into the king's holy presence,
.en: Sargon was brought into the presence of Ur-Zababa (who said:)

.en: Sargon answered his king:
.en: My king, this is my dream, which I will tell you about:
.en: There was a young woman who was as high as the heavens and as broad as the earth.
.en: She was firmly set as the base of a wall.
.en: For me, she drowned you in a great river, a river of blood."

r.en: After Enlil’s frown 
r.en: had slain Kiš as if it were the Bull of Heaven, 
r.en: had slaughtered the house of the land of Uruk in the dust as if it were a mighty bull, 
r.en: Then, to Sargon, king of Agade, 
r.en: from the south as far as the highlands did Enlil 
r.en: give the rulership and kingship. 
r.en: at that time, holy inanna established the sanctuary of Agade 
r.en: as her celebrated woman’s domain; 
r.en: she set up her throne in Ulmaš. 
.en: Like a young man building a house for the first time, 
.en: like a girl establishing a woman’s domain, 
.en: So that the warehouses would be provisioned; 
.en: that dwellings would be founded in the city; 
.en: that its people would eat splendid food; 
.en: that its people would drink splendid beverages; 
.en: that those bathed for holidays would rejoice in the courtyards; 
.en: that the people would throng the places of celebration; 
.en: that acquaintances would dine together; 
.en: that foreigners would cruise about like unusual birds in the sky; 
.en: that even Marhaši would be re-entered on the tribute rolls; 
.en: that monkeys, mighty elephants, water buffalo, exotic animals 
.en: would jostle each other in the public squares. 
.en: as well as thoroughbred dogs, lions, {mountain ibexes}, and alum sheep with long wool 
.en: holy inanna did not sleep as she ensured all of this. 
.en: She then filled Agade’s stores for emmer wheat with gold, 
.en: she filled its stores for white emmer wheat with silver; 
.en: she delivered copper, tin, and blocks of lapis lazuli to its granaries 
.en: and sealed its silos from outside. 
.en: She endowed its old women with the gift of giving counsel, 
.en: she endowed its old men with the gift of eloquence. 
.en: She endowed its young women with the gift of entertaining, 
.en: she endowed its young men with martial might, 
.en: she endowed its little ones with joy 
.en: The nursemaids who cared for the general’s children 
.en: played the drumsticks. 
.en: Inside the city tigi drums sounded; outside it, flutes and zamzam instruments. 
.en: Its harbour where ships moored was full of joy. 
.en: All foreign lands rested contentedly, 
.en: and their people experienced happiness. 
.en: Its king, the shepherd Naram-Suen, 
.en: rose as the daylight on the holy throne of Agade. 
.en: Its city wall, like a mountain, reached the heavens. 
.en: Its city-gates were like the Tigris {going to} the sea 
.en: when Inanna opened its portals 
.en: and made Sumer bring its own possessions upstream by boats. 
.en: The highland Martu, people ignorant of agriculture, 
.en: brought spirited cattle and kids for her. 
.en: The Meluḫans, the people of the black land, 
.en: brought exotic wares up to her. 
.en: Elam and Subir loaded themselves with goods for her as if they were packasses. 
.en: All the governors, the temple administrators, 
.en: and the accountants of the Gu-edina 
.en: regularly supplied the monthly and New Year offerings. 
.en: What a weariness all these caused at Agade’s city gates! 
.en: Holy inanna could hardly receive all these offerings. 
.en: As if she were a citizen there, she could not restrain (?) the desire (?) to prepare the ground for a temple. 
.en: But the statement coming from the E-kur was disquieting. 
.en: Because of Enlil (?) all Agade was reduced (?) to trembling, 
.en: and terror befell inanna in Ulmaš. 
.en: She left the city, returning to her home. 
.en: Like someone abandoning the young women of her woman’s domain, 
.en: Holy inanna abandoned the sanctuary of Agade 
.en: Like a warrior hurrying to arms, 
.en: she removed the gift of battle and fight from the city 
.en: and handed them over to the enemy. 
.en: Not even five or 10 days had passed 
.en: and the jewels of rulership, the royal crown, 
.en: the emblem and the royal throne bestowed on Agade, 
.en: did Ninurta bring back into his E-šu-me-ša. 
.en: Utu took away the eloquence of the city. 
.en: Enki took away its wisdom. 
.en: Its fearsomeness that reaches heaven, 
.en: An took up into the midst of heaven. 
.en: Its well-anchored holy mooring pole 
.en: Enki tore out from the abzu. 
.en: inanna took away its weapons. 
.en: The life of Agade’s sanctuary was brought to an end as if it had been only the life of a tiny carp in the deep waters, 
.en: and all the cities were watching it. 
.en: Like a mighty elephant, it bent its neck to the ground 
.en: while they all raised their horns like mighty bulls. 
.en: Like a dying dragon, it dragged its head on the earth 
.en: and they jointly deprived it of honour as in a battle. 
.en: Enlil would not let the kingdom of Agade occupy a pleasant, lasting residence, 
.en: that he would make its future altogether unfavourable, 
.en: that he would make its temples shake and would scatter its treasures - 
.en: - Naram-Suen saw that in a nocturnal vision. 
.en: He realised what the dream was about, but did not put into words, and did not discuss it with anyone. 
.en: ... temples shake ... 
.en: ... perform (?) extispicy regarding (?) his temple ... 
.en: Because of the E-kur, he put on mourning clothes, 
.en: covered his chariot with a reed mat, 
.en: tore the reed canopy off his ceremonial barge, 
.en: and gave away his royal paraphernalia. 
.en: Naram-Suen persisted for seven years! 
.en: Who has ever seen a king burying his head in his hands for seven years? 
en: He realised what the dream was about, but did not put into words, and did not discuss it with anyone. 
.en: Then he went to perform extispicy on a kid regarding the temple, 
.en: but the omen had nothing to say about the building of the temple. 
.en: For a second time he went to perform extispicy on a kid regarding the temple, 
.en: but the omen again had nothing to say about the building of the temple. 
.en: In order to change what had been inflicted (?) upon him, 
.en: he tried to to alter Enlil’s pronouncement. 
en: Because his subjects were dispersed, 
en: he now began a mobilization of his troops. 
en: Like a wrestler who is about to enter the great courtyard, 
en: he ...... his hands towards (?) the E-kur. 
en: Like an athlete bent to start a contest, 
en: he treated the giguna as if it were worth only thirty shekels. 
en: Like a robber plundering the city, 
en: he set tall ladders against the temple. 
en: To demolish E-kur as if it were a huge ship, 
en: to break up its soil like the soil of mountains where precious metals are mined, 
en: to splinter it like the lapis lazuli mountain, 
en: to prostrate it like a city inundated by Iškur; 
en: alhough the temple was not the Mountains of Cedar-felling, 
en: he had large axes cast, 
en: he had double-edged agasilig axes sharpened to be used against it. 
en: He set spades against its roots 
en: and it sank as low as the foundation of the Land. 
en: He put axes against its top, 
en: and the temple, like a dead soldier, bowed its neck before him, 
en: and all the foreign lands bowed their necks before him. 
en: He ripped out its drain pipes, 
en: and all the rain went back to the heavens. 
en: He tore off its upper lintel and the Land was deprived of its ornament. 
en: From its Gate from which Grain is never Diverted, he diverted grain, 
en: and the Land was deprived of grain. 
en: He struck the Gate of Well-Being with the pickaxe, 
en: and well-being was subverted in all the foreign lands. 
en: As if they were for great tracts of land with wide carp-filled waters, 
en: he cast large spades to be used against the E-kur. 
en: The people could see the bedchamber, its room which knows no daylight. 
en: They could look into the holy treasure chest of the gods. 
en: its laḫama deities of the great pilasters standing at the temple, 
en: though they had committed no sacrilege, 
en: were thrown into the fire by Naram-Suen. 
en: The cedar, cypress, juniper and boxwood, 
en: the woods of its giguna, were ... by him. 
en: He put its gold in containers 
en: and put its silver in leather bags. 
en: He filled the docks with its copper, as if it were a huge transport of grain. 
en: The silversmiths were re-shaping its silver, 
en: jewellers were re-shaping its precious stones, 
en: smiths were beating its copper. 
en: Though they were not the goods of a plundered city, 
en: large ships were moored at the temple, 
en: large ships were moored at Enlil’s temple 
en: and its possessions were taken away from the city. 
en: With the possessions being taken away from the city, 
en: good sense left Agade. 
en: As the ships moved away from the docks, Agade’s intelligence was removed. 
en: The roaring storm that subjugates the entire land, 
en: the rising deluge that cannot be confronted, 
en: Enlil was considering what should be destroyed in return for the wrecking of his beloved E-kur. 
en: He lifted his gaze towards the Gubin mountains, 
en: and made all the inhabitants of the broad mountain ranges descend (?). 
en: Those who do not resemble other people, who are not reckoned as part of the Land, 
en: the Gutians, an unbridled people, 
en: with human intelligence but canine instincts and monkeys’ features - 
en: Enlil brought them out of the mountains. 
en: Like small birds they swooped on the ground in great flocks. 
en: Because of Enlil, they stretched their arms out across the plain like a net for animals. 
en: Nothing escaped their clutches, 
en: no one left their grasp. 
en: Messengers no longer travelled the highways, 
en: the courier’s boat no longer passed along the rivers. 
en: The Gutians drove the trusty (?) goats of Enlil out of their folds and compelled their herdsmen to follow them, they drove the cows out of their pens and compelled their cowherds to follow them. 
en: they drove the cows out of their pens and compelled their cowherds to follow them. 
en: Prisoners manned the watch. 
en: Brigands occupied the highways. 
en: The doors of the city gates of the Land lay dislodged in mud, 
en: and all the foreign lands uttered bitter cries from the walls of their cities. 
en: They established gardens for themselves within the cities, and not as usual on the wide plain outside. 
en: As if it had been before the time when cities were built and founded, 
en: the large arable tracts yielded no grain, 
en: the inundated tracts yielded no fish, 
en: the irrigated orchards yielded no syrup or wine, 
en: the thick clouds (?) did not rain, the mašgurum plant did not grow. 
en: In those days, oil for one shekel was only half a litre, 
en: grain for one shekel was only half a litre, 
en: wool for one shekel was only one mina, 
en: fish for one shekel filled only one ban measure 
en: these sold at such prices in the markets of the cities! 
en: Those who lay down on the roof, died on the roof; 
en: those who lay down in the house were not buried. 
en: People were flailing at themselves from hunger. 
en: By the Ki-ur, Enlil’s great place, 
en: dogs were packed together in the silent streets; 
en: if two men walked there they would be devoured by them, 
en: and if three men walked there they would be devoured by them. 
en: Noses were punched (?), heads were smashed (?), 
en: noses (?) were piled up, heads were sown like seeds. 
en: Honest people were confounded with traitors, 
en: heroes lay dead on top of heroes, 
en: the blood of traitors ran upon the blood of honest men. 
en: At that time, Enlil rebuilt his great sanctuaries 
en: into small reed (?) sanctuaries 
en: and from east to west he reduced their storehouses. 
en: The old women who survived those days, 
en: the old men who survived those days, 
en: and the chief lamentation singer who survived those years 
en: for seven days and seven nights 
en: set up seven balaĝ drums, 
en: ub, meze, and lilis drums made them resound to Enlil like Iškur. 
en: The old women did not restrain the cry “Alas for my city!” 
en: The old men did not restrain the cry “Alas for its people!” 
en: The lamentation singer did not restrain the cry “Alas for the E-kur!” 
en: Its young women did not restrain from tearing their hair. 
en: Its young men did not restrain from sharpening their knives. 
en: Their laments were as if Enlil’s ancestors 
en: were performing a lament in the awe-inspiring Holy Mound by the holy knees of Enlil. 
en: Because of this, Enlil entered his holy bedchamber and lay down fasting. 
en: At that time, Suen, Enki, inanna, Ninurta, Iškur, Utu, Nuska, and Nisaba, the great gods 
en: cooled Enlil’s heart with cool water and prayed to him: 
en: “Enlil, may the city that destroyed your city be treated as your city has been treated! 
en: May the one that defiled your giguna be treated as Nibru! 
en: In this city, may heads fill the wells! 
en: May no one find his acquaintances there, 
en: may brother not recognise brother! 
en: May its young woman be cruelly killed in her woman’s domain, 
en: may its old man cry in distress for his slain wife! 
en: May its pigeons moan on their window ledges, 
en: may its small birds be smitten in their nooks, 
en: may it live in constant anxiety like a timid pigeon!” 
en: Again, Suen, Enki, inanna, Ninurta, Iškur, Utu, Nuska and Nisaba, all the gods whosoever, 
en: turned their attention to the city, 
en: and cursed Agade severely: 
en: “City, you pounced on E-kur: it is as if you had pounced on Enlil! 
en: Agade, you pounced on E-kur: it is as if you had pounced on Enlil! 
en: May your holy walls, to their highest point, resound with mourning! 
en: May your giguna be reduced to a pile of dust! 
en: May your pilasters with the standing lahama deities 
en: fall to the ground like tall young men drunk on wine! 
en: May your clay be returned to its abzu, 
en: may it be clay cursed by Enki! 
en: May your grain be returned to its furrow, 
en: may it be grain cursed by Ezina! 
en: May your timber be returned to its forest, 
en: may it be timber cursed by Ninilduma! 
en: May the cattle slaughterer slaughter his wife, 
en: may your sheep butcher butcher his child! 
en: May water wash away your pauper as he is looking for ...! 
en: May your prostitute hang herself at the entrance to her brothel! 
en: May your pregnant (?) priestesses and cult prostitutes abort (?) their children! 
en: May your gold be bought for the price of silver, 
en: may your silver be bought for the price of pyrite (?), 
en: and may your copper be bought for the price of lead!” 
en: “Agade, may your strong man be deprived of his strength, 
en: so that he will be unable to lift his sack of provisions and ..., 
en: and will not have the joy of controlling your superior asses; may he lie idle all day! 
en: May this make the city die of hunger! 
en: May your citizens, who used to eat fine food, lie hungry, 
en: may your ... man 
en: eat the coating on his roof, 
en: The leather hinges on the main door of his father’s house, 
en: may he chew their leather hinges! 
en: May depression descend upon your palace, built for joy! 
en: May the evils of the desert, the silent place, howl continuously!” 
en: “Your uzga precinct, established for purification ceremonies, 
en: may foxes that frequent its ruin mounds and brush it with their tails 
en: Your gateways, established for the Land, 
en: May the ukuku, the bird of depression, make its nest in them! 
en: In your city that could not sleep because of the tigi drums, 
en: that could not rest from its joy, 
en: may the bulls of Nanna that fill the pens 
en: bellow like those who wander in the desert, the silent place! 
en: May the grass grow long on your canal-bank tow-paths, 
en: may the grass of mourning grow on your highways laid for waggons! 
en: Moreover, on your tow-paths built up with canal sediment, 
en: may ... wild rams (?) and alert snakes of the mountains allow no one to pass! 
en: In your plains where fine grass grows, may the reed of lamentation grow! 
en: Agade, may brackish water flow, where fresh water flowed for you! 
en: If someone decides, “I will dwell in this city!,” may he not enjoy the pleasures of a dwelling place! 
en: If someone decides, “I will rest in Agade!,” may he not enjoy the pleasures of a resting place!” 
en: And before Utu on that very day, so it was! 
en: On its canal bank tow-paths, the grass grew long. 
en: On its highways laid for waggons, the grass of mourning grew. 
en: Moreover, on its tow-paths built up with canal sediment, 
en: wild rams (?) and alert snakes of the mountains allowed no one to pass. 
en: On its plains, where fine grass grew, now the reeds of lamentation grew. 
en: Agade’s flowing fresh water flowed as brackish water. 
en: When someone decided, “I will dwell in that city!,” he could not enjoy the pleasures of a dwelling place. 
en: When someone decided, “I will rest in Agade!,” 
en: For the destruction of Agade, Inanna be praised!

.en: 1st kirugu. 
.en: She has let the breeze haunt her sheepfold, she groans grievously over it.

.en: 2nd kirugu. 
.en: In his righteous destroyed city its lament is bitter.
